text-decoration-line: none;\">August 15, 2017 at 12:15 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_63MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">IN 1947 WHEN THE WHITE INVADER LEFT INDIA , WE WERE REDUCED TO BEGGARS</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">THE WHITE INVADER ROBBED BHARATMATA BLIND-- AND ROTHSCHILDs AGENTS LIKE GANDHI TOLD ANGRY INDIANS TO LOVE THE WHITE INVADER</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">DURING PARTITION THE BABUS OF INDIA AND PAKISTAN FOUGHT OVER INKPOTS AND CHAIRS--SUCH WAS THE POVERTY</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">IN 70 YEARS INDIA IS NOW THIS PLANETs NO 3 ECONOMY</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">NO 1 ECONOMY-- USA IS 20 TRILLION IN DEBT</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">NO 2 ECONOMY --CHINA ECONOMY IS A BUBBLE WITHIN A BUBBLE</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">INDIA IS THE ONLY HEALTHY ECONOMY</span></div>\n<div style=\"text-align: left;\">\n<span style=\"color: red; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif; font-size: large; font-weight: bold;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"color: red; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif; font-size: large;\"></span><br />\n<div style=\"text-align: left;\">\n<span style=\"color: red; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif; font-size: large;\"><b>TODAY IF CHINA WANTS A WAR WITH INDIA-- WE WILL DESTROY CHINA MILITARILY AND ECONOMICALLY.</b></span></div>\n<span style=\"color: red; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif; font-size: large;\">\n</span>\n<br />\n<div style=\"text-align: left;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">capt ajit vadakayil</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">..</span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; float: left; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n<img src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-DUOJiRC5obw/UwiDtflONuI/AAAAAAAAppU/hpxnNJK2CIw/s113/*\" style=\"border: 1px solid rgb(238, 238, 238); max-width: 36px;\" /></div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c1882076012697512781\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_281M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2016/06/gpi-dog-shall-wag-gdp-tail-not-vice.html?showComment=1502779016435#c1882076012697512781\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">August 15, 2017 at 12:06 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_281MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nChina has been doing currency manipulation. China buys or sells foreign currency in exchange for their own domestic currency, generally with the intention of influencing the exchange rate and trade policy.<br />\n<br />\nTwo decades ago, there was a marked increase in American imports of Chinese goods. China\u2019s central bank allegedly devalued yuan by buying large amounts of US dollars with yuan, thus increasing the supply of the yuan in the foreign exchange market, while increasing the demand for US dollars, thus increasing the price of USD<br />\n<br />\nChina intentionally devalued its currency to boost its exports to the United States and as a result, widening its trade deficit with the US. The shadow govt running USA did NOT impose tariffs on Chinese goods. USA should have branded China s a currency manipulator long ago.<br />\n<br />\nThe more depreciated China\u2019s exchange rate \u2014 the higher the price of the dollar in yuan \u2014 the more dollars China earns from exports, and the fewer dollars it spends on imports.<br />\n<br />\nBy keeping its currency artificially weak \u2014 a higher price of dollars in terms of yuan \u2014 China generates a dollar surplus; this means the Chinese government has to buy up the excess dollars.<br />\n<br />\nChina suppressed the rise of the her currency to maintain a competitive advantage for its exports<br />\n<br />\nBy 2007, China\u2019s broad trade surplus hit 10 percent of its gross domestic product \u2014 an unheard-of imbalance for an economy this large. And its surplus with the United States amounted to a full third of the American deficit with the world.<br />\n<br />\nBy December 2012, China\u2019s foreign exchange reserve held roughly 3.3 trillion USD, making it the highest foreign exchange reserve in the world. Roughly 60% of this reserve was composed of US government bonds and debentures.<br />\n<br />\nChina\u2019s currency was undervalued against the dollar by 30 percent from 2003 to 2013. By intervening massively in currency markets\u2014up to 2 USD billion a day in 2007\u2014China kept the yuan priced artificially low.<br />\n<br />\nThis was tantamount to a form of mercantilism\u2014intensive government intercession in support of maintaining a trade surplus\u2014using a cheapened currency, which achieves an attractive price for export goods while keeping prices high for imports. China ran a trade surplus at nearly 10 percent of GDP, while the U.S. floundered during the financial crisis.<br />\n<br />\nChina also imposed tight capital controls, largely walling off its stocks, bonds, and banks from foreign investors by imposing extensive restrictions. Chinese laws require foreign companies to share advanced technology in exchange for access to the country\u2019s vast market.<br />\n<br />\nThe United States defines currency manipulation as having a trade value exceeding US$50 billion and a trade deficit of $20 billion. Based on the numbers alone, China fits the profile, with annual US-China trade nearing $520 billion and a deficit exceeding $300 billion in 2016.<br />\n<br />\nBlaming China for the job losses and factory closures will not bring back jobs or manufacturing to the US.<br />\n<br />\nTrump has declined to name China a currency manipulator.. Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974 allows POTUS to unilaterally impose tariffs or other trade restrictions to protect U.S. industries from \"unfair trade practices\" of foreign countries, such as trade agreement violations, or \"discriminatory\" actions that burden U.S. commerce.<br />\n<br />\nCONTINUED TO 2-</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" id=\"bc_0_281BR\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 36px; margin-top: 1em;\">\n<span id=\"bc_0_281b+seedEZD\" kind=\"d\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"comment-thread inline-thread\" id=\"bc_0_282T\" kind=\"t\" style=\"background-color: #eeeeee; margin: 8px 0px; padding: 0.5em 1em;\" t=\"0\" u=\"0\">\n<ol class=\"thread-chrome thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_282TC\" style=\"list-style-type: none; padding: 0px;\" unselectable=\"on\"><div style=\"zoom: 1;\" unselectable=\"on\">\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<li class=\"comment\" id=\"bc_0_282B\" kind=\"b\" style=\"border-bottom: 0px; margin: 0px 0px 16px; padding: 16px 0px 0px;\"><div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"float: left; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n<span id=\"bc_0_281b+seedEZD\" kind=\"d\"></span></div>\n<span id=\"bc_0_281b+seedEZD\" kind=\"d\">\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c209126947174769054\" style=\"margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_282M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2016/06/gpi-dog-shall-wag-gdp-tail-not-vice.html?showComment=1502779051103#c209126947174769054\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">August 15, 2017 at 12:07 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_282MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nCONTINUED FROM 1-<br />\n<br />\nNow China is stealthily and deliberately appreciated the yuan against the US dollar and other major currencies to avoid being labeled as a currency manipulator.<br />\n<br />\nChina has a MAD Plan B: the Belt and Road Initiative, other markets around the world, and its huge domestic one, enabling it to cushion the losses from a trade war, notwithstanding that it will encounter higher unemployment and slower economic growth in the short run.<br />\n<br />\nCHINA IS A GRANDMASTER IN REVERSE ENGINEERING. THERE IS A STATE BUDGET FOR THIS.<br />\n<br />\nReverse engineering is taking apart an object to see how it works in order to duplicate or EVEN enhance the object.<br />\n<br />\nSoftware reverse engineering involves reversing a program's machine code (the string of 0s and 1s that are sent to the logic processor) back into the source code that it was written in, using program language statements<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: red;\">http://www.theepochtimes.com/n3/1699756-7-military-weapons-china-copied-from-the-united-states/</span><br />\n<br />\nWhen a new machine comes to market, competing manufacturers buy one machine and disassemble it to learn how it was built and how it works. Reverse engineering is common in both hardware and software. Several companies have succeeded in producing Intel-compatible microprocessors through reverse engineering<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: red;\">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r8Vq5NV4Ens</span><br />\n<br />\ncapt ajit vadakayil<br />\n..</div>\n</div>\n</span></li>\n<span id=\"bc_0_281b+seedEZD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<span id=\"bc_0_281b+seedEZD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></ol>\n<span id=\"bc_0_281b+seedEZD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<span id=\"bc_0_281b+seedEZD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b><br />\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c6589841268920392802\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_95M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. text-decoration-line: none;\">August 17, 2017 at 8:58 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_95MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nhttps://www.theguardian.com/business/2017/aug/15/imf-warns-china-debt-slowdown-financial-crisis<br />\n<br />\nAAAAAHHHHHHAAAAAAA<br />\n<br />\nCUNTS IN IMF HAS FINALLY WOKEN UP AND SEEN THE ELEPHANT IN THE FUCKIN' ROOM ?<br />\n<br />\nCHINAs ECONOMY IS A HOUSE OF CARDS<br />\n<br />\nIT WILL COLLAPSE AS SOON AS INDIA STOPS IMPORTING GOOD FROM CHINA<br />\n<br />\nWE DONT NEED CHINA AS A TRADING PARTNER<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: red;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2017/08/can-china-afford-war-with-india-come-on.html<br /><br />http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2017/07/can-china-afford-war-with-india-come-on.html</span><br />\n<br />\nThe IMF said debt as a proportion of gross domestic product would rise from 235% to almost 300% by 2022<br />\n<br />\nSORRY-- THIS BLOGSITE IS SMARTER AND MORE HONEST THAN ROTHSCHILDs IMF<br />\n<br />\nCHINAs DEBT TO GDP RATIO IS A SHOCKING 420 % --total Chinese debt at all levels (household, corporate, bank and government)..<br />\n<br />\nMAD CHINESE COMMIE RULERS FIGURED THAT THE ONLY WAY TO PREVENT A PEOPLEs REVOLUTION IS TO PAINT A ROSY PICTURE OF THEIR SINKING ECONOMY.<br />\n<br />\nParty leaders estimated they needed to sustain a minimum annual growth rate of 8 per cent if they were to contain political unrest that could threaten authoritarian rule--<br />\n<br />\nTHE AFTER MATH OF A \"DEATH TO COMMUNISM\" REVOLUTION IS ALWAYS --COMMIE LEADERS AND THEIR ATTACK DOG MEDIA BEING HUNG BY THEIR NECKS BY A SHORT ROPE AND A LAMP POST<br />\n<br />\nThe solution was to unleash what economists have called the greatest example of monetary easing in history \u2014 an enormous wave of easy loans channelled through the state-owned banking system.<br />\n<br />\nChinese economy addicted to borrowing and afflicted with serious asset bubbles.<br />\n<br />\nIT TAKES INTELLIGENCE TO SEE THIS BUBBLE WITHIN A BUBBLE --CUNTS IN IMF AND ROTHSCHILDs RATING AGENCIES CANT SEE IT<br />\n<br />\nIt is TOO LATE for China to take corrective action -- to to wean the country off this debt dependence<br />\n<br />\nSizzling property prices, a groaning debt load, wealthy tourists and tycoons willing to slap down eye-popping sums for art: China is starting to look like Japan before its economic bubble burst in the early 90s.<br />\n<br />\nChina was also downgraded this summer by Moody's with the credit rating agency citing the country's ballooning debt,<br />\n<br />\nPresident Xi Jinping as if kicked on his balls has secretly commissioned a THINK TANK study to help China avoid Japan's pitfalls, as growth slows and ratings agencies sound the alarm over its debt.<br />\n<br />\nJapan was the original Asian tiger, with growth surging at an average 9.0 percent annually between 1955 and 1973 in the long postwar boom, turning it into one of the world's great economic powers.<br />\n<br />\nChina has also basked in heady growth -- replacing Japan as the world's number two economy in 2010 -- and has not seen a single recession in decades.<br />\n<br />\nChina's debt is around 420 % of GDP, up from around 136 % before the 2008 financial crisis.<br />\n<br />\nThe Chinese economy and its currency are tightly controlled by MAD COMMIES<br />\n<br />\nHOW MANY BUSINESS SCHOOLS IN INDIA HAVE A CHAPTER ON \"JAPANs LOST DECADE ?<br />\n<br />\nALL THESE USELESS ECONOMICS PROFESSORS DESERVE TO BE SACKED.<br />\n<span style=\"color: red;\"><br />http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/06/gpi-dog-shall-wag-gdp-tail-not-vice.html</span><br />\n<br />\nThe speed of Japan\u2019s post-war economic recovery was remarkable, but it culminated in a hugely overheated economy in the late 1980s. When the bubble burst the country found itself in an economic wilderness, the so-called \u2018lost decade\u2019.<br />\n<br />\nBy 1985, just 40 years later, Japan was enjoying a period of unparalleled prosperity-- a HOUSE OF CARDS<br />\n<br />\nJapanese private citizens went on a buying spree of their own, flying all over the world in record numbers, shopping for Louis Vuitton handbags and Armani suits, drinking the finest wines and staying in the best hotels in Europe and the US. Not unlike today\u2019s Chinese tourists<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: red;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2011/02/great-american-depression-capt-ajit.html</span><br />\n<br />\nCONTINUED TO 2--</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" id=\"bc_0_95BR\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; margin: 8px 0px; padding: 0.5em 1em;\" t=\"0\" u=\"0\">\n<span id=\"bc_0_95b+seedBbiuD\" kind=\"d\"><span class=\"thread-toggle thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_94TT\" kind=\"g\" style=\"cursor: pointer; display: inline-block;\"><span class=\"thread-count\" id=\"bc_0_94TN\"></span></span></span><br />\n<div class=\"thread-dropContainer thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_94TD\">\n<span id=\"bc_0_95b+seedBbiuD\" kind=\"d\"><span class=\"thread-toggle thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_94TT\" kind=\"g\" style=\"cursor: pointer; display: inline-block;\"><span class=\"thread-count\" id=\"bc_0_94TN\"><span class=\"thread-drop\"></span></span></span></span></div>\n<span id=\"bc_0_95b+seedBbiuD\" kind=\"d\"><span class=\"thread-toggle thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_94TT\" kind=\"g\" style=\"cursor: pointer; display: inline-block;\"><span class=\"thread-count\" id=\"bc_0_94TN\">\n</span></span><br />\n</span><br />\n<ol class=\"thread-chrome thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_94TC\" style=\"list-style-type: none; padding: 0px;\"><span id=\"bc_0_95b+seedBbiuD\" kind=\"d\">\n<li class=\"comment\" id=\"bc_0_94B\" kind=\"b\" style=\"border-bottom: 0px; margin: 0px 0px 16px; padding: 16px 0px 0px;\"><div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"float: left; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n<img src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-57G2xiZ-5tM/WJwrrVpmOmI/AAAAAAABQqo/-9wsspdm4RAiWSVRYXpBpkgoVBQdEyLRQCK4B/s35/*\" style=\"border: 1px solid rgb(238, 238, 238); max-width: 36px;\" /></div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c6719799509286276425\" style=\"margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_94M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2017/08/rajnikanth-entry-into-politics-babaji.html?showComment=1502983772719#c6719799509286276425\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">August 17, 2017 at 8:59 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_94MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nCONTINUED FROM 1-<br />\n<br />\nWhile the good times continued to roll, Japanese banks did not ask borrowers too many questions about how loans would be repaid or what would happen if land values started to fall. Neither the Bank of Japan nor the Finance Ministry seemed to know how to stop the party either. These were truly heady times in Japan. Today if you go to Las Vegas Chinese are the big gamblers in casinos.<br />\n<br />\nAt the end of 1989 the Nikkei 225 Stock Index had reached nearly 39,200 points and was in uncharted territory<br />\n<br />\nRecognising the unsustainability of the bubble the Finance Ministry at last took decisive action in late 1989, raising interest rates sharply. This was followed soon afterwards by an order to banks to curtail their property lending. The Nikkei took a severe downward spiral<br />\n<br />\nBy the end of the year the Nikkei had lost more than $2.21 trillion in value<br />\n<br />\nWith stocks and real estate prices tumbling, this effectively brought an end to both the bubble era and more than two decades of powerful Japanese economic growth and rapid overseas business expansion.<br />\n<br />\nIn the words of CHOOT Richard Koo, Chief Economist at the Nomura Research Institute, the Japanese government had implemented, \u201cOne of the most successful economic policies in history.\u201d<br />\n<br />\nProperty values in Japan eventually plummeted 90.2% from their peak. The massive falls in the value of both stocks and real estate meant that the country lost wealth equivalent to 3.3 years of GDP.<br />\n<br />\nThe bubble economy came to an end with such speed and in such dramatic fashion that to say that the Japanese government was caught WITH THEIR LANGOTS DOWN would be an understatement<br />\n<br />\nThe NOT SO BRIGHT Japanese government\u2019s first reaction was to reduce interest rates to 0% to try to spur economic growth, but this had no effect on either asset prices or economic activity<br />\n<br />\nIt was not until the mid 1990s, more than five years after the bubble had burst, that Japanese banks began writing off their bad debts. It was as if they were in denial and somehow expected the stock market and real estate prices to stage a remarkable recovery. This of course never happened<br />\n<br />\nIt was not until 2001 that Japan\u2019s economy showed the first signs of getting back on its feet. It had been a decade which forced Japanese companies to make major structural changes in order to adapt to the new HARSH reality.<br />\n<br />\nPOOR CHINA<br />\n<br />\nTHROW SOME BREAD CRUMBS IN THEIR GENERAL DIRECTION<br />\n<br />\ncapt ajit vadakayil<br />\n..</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n</span></ol>\n<span id=\"bc_0_95b+seedBbiuD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<span id=\"bc_0_95b+seedBbiuD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b><br />\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c1894169662784936220\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_206M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. Gaining favours from regulators and party elites are the surest path to good fortune.<br />\n<br />\nIt is precisely this type of closed minded thinking coupled with cronyism and exclusive capitalism with Chinese characteristics that will continue to kill innovation and stifle creative thinking across China.<br />\n<br />\nMAXIMUM INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY THEFT BY WAY OF REVERSE ENGINEERING HAPPENS IN CHINA<br />\n<br />\nChina\u2019s big internet companies are basically copies of their western counterparts.<br />\n<br />\nStealing intellectual property has enormously benefited Chinese companies. But, it has crippled their ability to develop the next version or innovate. Any idiot can figure this out<br />\n<br />\nChina's corporate espionage is so vast it constitutes a national US security emergency, with China targeting virtually every sector of the U.S. economy, and costing American companies hundreds of billions of dollars in losses -- and more than 2.4 million jobs.<br />\n<br />\nGetting CEOs from those US companies to talk is nearly impossible because most of them still have business in China and don't want to be cut out of its huge market--and of course huge kickbacks they get to keep quiet. Some of these QUIETUDE is obtained by HONEY TRAPS<br />\n<br />\nAMSC makes software that controls the operation of wind turbines, and Sinovel was once its biggest customer, accounting for nearly 80 percent of its revenues. In March 2011, Sinovel suddenly stopped accepting shipments from AMSC, canceling contracts and devastating the Devens company, which has since cut nearly 60 percent of its global workforce.<br />\n<br />\nThree months later, AMSC believes it discovered why: It found a replica of its software operating in a Sinovel turbine in China. The company later sued Sinovel for more than $1.2 billion in Chinese courts.<br />\n<br />\nThe US criminal case, ironically, stems from Sinovel\u2019s sale of four turbines to Massachusetts customers \u2014 each turbine operating with the allegedly stolen software, according to the indictment. State records show that at least one of the turbines, at the Massachusetts Water Resources Authority\u2019s DeLauri Sewer Pump Station in Charlestown, was purchased using $4.7 million in stimulus funds.<br />\n<br />\nFollowing the indictment Thursday, AMSC called on the Obama administration and Congress to \u201cre-evaluate the US trade relationship with China,\u201d given that companies in China are \u201cbrazenly stealing trade secrets.\u201d<br />\n<br />\n\u201cThis clearly demonstrates that the rights of foreign businesses in China are not currently protected,\u201d AMSC chief executive Daniel P. McGahn said in a statement.<br />\n<br />\nSinovel could not be reached for comment Thursday, but the company has previously denied wrongdoing. Sinovel has countersued AMSC in China, seeking $200 million for breach of contract and other claims. Sinovel is being investigated by the China Securities Regulatory Commission over possible violations of security laws and regulations, according to news reports out of China.<br />\n<br />\nThe federal indictment, filed in Wisconsin, where AMSC develops its wind turbine control software, charges Sinovel with conspiracy to commit trade secret theft, criminal copyright infringement, and wire fraud. By stealing AMSC\u2019s technology, the indictment charged, Sinovel cheated the Devens company of more than $800 million.<br />\n<br />\nCONTINUED TO 2-</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" id=\"bc_0_206BR\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 36px; margin-top: 1em;\">\n<span id=\"bc_0_206b+seedDOD\" kind=\"d\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"comment-thread inline-thread\" id=\"bc_0_207T\" kind=\"t\" style=\"background-color: #eeeeee; margin: 8px 0px; padding: 0.5em 1em;\" t=\"0\" u=\"0\">\n<ol class=\"thread-chrome thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_207TC\" style=\"list-style-type: none; padding: 0px;\" unselectable=\"on\"><div style=\"zoom: 1;\" unselectable=\"on\">\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<li class=\"comment\" id=\"bc_0_207B\" kind=\"b\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 16px; padding: 16px 0px 8px;\"><div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"float: left; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n<span id=\"bc_0_206b+seedDOD\" kind=\"d\"></span></div>\n<span id=\"bc_0_206b+seedDOD\" kind=\"d\">\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c1312903345748604112\" style=\"margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_207M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2017/08/rajnikanth-entry-into-politics-babaji.html?showComment=1503150432468#c1312903345748604112\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">August 19, 2017 at 7:17 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_207MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nCONTINUED FROM 1-<br />\n<br />\nThe indictment alleges that several months after AMSC sued Sinovel, the Chinese company sold turbines to customers in Charlestown, Fairhaven, and Scituate that contained the stolen software. One of the turbines, near the wastewater treatment plant on the Driftway in Scituate, was partially financed by a state bond, according to public records.<br />\n<br />\nIf convicted, Sinovel faces a maximum penalty on each count of five years of probation and a fine \u2013 on each count \u2014 of up to double the more than $800 million the indictment alleges AMSC lost.<br />\n<br />\n\u201cThe ongoing cases in China serve as a test for whether American corporations can depend on Chinese courts to address corporate espionage of intellectual property adequately,\u201d said Mark Wu, an assistant professor at Harvard Law School.<br />\n<br />\nThe US Department of Justice has made a concerted effort to crack down on intellectual property theft in recent years, creating a strategic plan and a task force in 2010 aimed at addressing intellectual property crimes ..<br />\n<br />\nLast year, the government brought charges against a company controlled by the Chinese government for attempting to steal trade secrets for a valuable white pigment used in paper, plastics, and paint from E.I. du Pont de Nemours &amp; Co., of Wilmington, Del.<br />\n<br />\nIn China, AMSC has filed four cases against Sinovel, all which are winding their way through the Chinese legal system and could take from months to years to resolve.<br />\n<br />\nAMSC\u2019s situation has gained the attention of top-level officials in Europe, China, and the United States, including Vice President Joe Biden and Secretary of State John Kerry.<br />\n<br />\n\u201cWe believe our topic is on the agendas of President Barack Obama, as well as Chinese President Xi Jinping,\u201d McGahn, the AMSC chief executive, said during a recent call with analysts.<br />\n<br />\nAMSC has been embroiled in the case since 2011, when one of its field crews in China came across the allegedly stolen technology. An investigation launched by the company led to the 2011 conviction of an AMSC engineer in Austria, who was sentenced to a year in jail after pleading guilty to transferring software source code to Sinovel to help the Chinese replicate AMSC\u2019s technology.<br />\n<br />\nThursday\u2019s indictment offered additional details about how that convicted AMSC engineer, Dejan Karabasevic, allegedly worked with two Sinovel employees to copy the Devens company\u2019s technology. According to the court filing, Sinovel offered Karabasevic a six-year, $1.7 million contract and gave him an apartment in Beijing, as well as equipment, including a laptop, to transfer code and modify AMSC\u2019s technology.<br />\n<br />\nIn several instant messaging chats, according to the indictment, Karabasevic allegedly told the Sinovel employees he had transferred \u201cfull code\u201d to the company, and if they succeeded in adapting the technology Sinovel could \u201cseparate from AMSC.\u201d When Sinovel did break, AMSC\u2019s stock and revenues plunged. Layoffs have cut the company\u2019s workforce to 362 employees from 842, according to company financial filings.<br />\n<br />\nMcGahn has said he remains confident the company will survive the legal battle with Sinovel and prosper.<br />\n<br />\nRevenue increased 14 percent in fiscal 2012, to $87.4 million from $76.5 million in fiscal 2011. Losses were cut in half to $66.1 million. McGahn told analysts in mid-June that the company expects to be profitable by the end of its fiscal 2014.<br />\n<br />\nSinovel with support from Commie govt has countersued AMSC ( American Superconductor Corp.) in China, seeking $200 million for breach of contract and other claims.<br />\n<br />\nSeveral months after AMSC sued Sinovel, the Chinese company sold turbines to customers in USA which contained the stolen software. Chinese copycats have become more adept at exploiting procedural loopholes and invalidating legitimate patents and trademarks<br />\n<br />\nTrump must take aggressive retaliatory actions against China such as tariffs on Chinese imports or rescinding licenses for Chinese companies wanting to do business in the U.S. Rothschild and Bilderberg club are on the side of China<br />\n<br />\nCounterfeit electronic components have proliferated in recent years, including integrated circuits (ICs), relays, circuit breakers, fuses, ground fault receptacles, and cable assemblies, as well as connectors. The value of counterfeit electronic components is estimated to total 5 % of global sales<br />\n<br />\nCounterfeit devices have been reverse-engineered (also called a Chinese Blueprint due to its prevalence in China) to produce a product that looks identical and performs like the original, and able to pass physical and electrical tests<br />\n<br />\nCounterfeit electronic parts from China are 'flooding' into critical U.S. military systems, including special operations helicopters and surveillance planes--and poor USA dont even know about it.<br />\n<br />\nChina sometimes requires source code reviews as a condition to import commercial software<br />\n<br />\nIn April 2017, a Dutch employee of Siemens, working within the energy arm of Siemens, charged with stealing the intellectual property of his employer and attempting to share it with China.-- again beware of CHINESE HONEY PUSSY<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: red;\">http://fortune.com/2017/05/21/ibm-employee-theft-secrets-china/</span><br />\n<br />\nXu met with US agents-- in meeting he said he could write scripts to conceal the code's origin, and that he could also modify the software's command line interface with the same objective.<br />\n<br />\nMicrosoft, IBM and Intel have given Chinese officials short shrift after the government demanded to see their top-secret source code and blueprints.<br />\n<br />\nChina\u2019s first cyber security law will increase costs for multinationals, leave them vulnerable to industrial espionage and give Chinese companies an unfair advantage.. The measure allows Beijing to request computer program source code, which is usually known only by the software developer<br />\n<br />\nIt will help China steal trade secrets or intellectual property from foreign companies.<br />\n<br />\n<br />\nMultinationals will be hardest hit, as the data localisation measures prevent them pooling client data in cloud storage databases across the world. The need to store some data on China-based servers and the rest elsewhere will add to fragmentation and cost.<br />\n<br />\nCloud storage companies are affected. Companies are now switching data from Amazon Web Services in Singapore to Alibaba\u2019s China cloud service.<br />\n<br />\nALIBABA the Chinese online retailer and its market place Taobao have long been accused of being a platform for counterfeit goods.<br />\n<br />\nAlibaba was suspended from the International Anti Counterfeiting Coalition (IACC) watchdog over piracy concerns.<br />\n<br />\nJack Ma of ALIBABA is one of China\u2019s richest men, with a fortune valued at nearly $31 billion.<br />\n<br />\n<br />\nAlibaba\u2019s cloud business is participating in two labs: the first to support online data mining and cloud-based processing for the industrial sector; the other will build a platform for big data software.<br />\n<br />\nTRUMP-- WANT MORE JOBS IN USA ? There was no miracle in it. But it gets worse...much worse. That makes it difficult to see how much of the debt is worth investing in, or how much is bad enough to implode.<br />\n<br />\nIf China\u2019s trajectory continues, then it will be looking at an economic slump sooner than later.<br />\n<br />\nIn the recent years, China\u2019s big state-owned companies and powerful local governments have borrowed trillions of dollars. Millions of Chinese residents have taken in loans and mortgages to simply lead a middle-class lifestyle.<br />\n<br />\nThis has resulted in a big rush in buying real estate. Many having taken loans and mortgages that are well beyond their means. This is similar to the mortgage crisis in 2007 that resulted in the global recession.<br />\n<br />\nThe situation is so bad that even Chinese bank executives are willing to say they're in a bubble. Chinese debt is so large its scale is becoming almost unimaginable.<br />\n<br />\nThe China banking sector is about three times the size of its economy. Credit growth in China is now so large that the margin of error for estimates of its size now falls into the trillions.. Chinese corporate debt is more than 200% of GDP.<br />\n<br />\nThe Chinese authorities have tightened bank regulation in order to reduce leverage in the financial sector. font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_220M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2017/11/blockchain-smart-contracts-hashgraphs.html?showComment=1509819052632#c280946980446527899\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">November 4, 2017 at 11:40 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_220MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nALL THIS PROPAGANDA BY THAT MEDIA BASTARD HU XIJIN ( EDITOR OF GLOBAL TIMES ) THAT PRESIDENT XI IS THE NEW MAO WONT WORK<br />\n<br />\nThe Chinese credit bubble is a ticking time bomb. That bubble is primed to explode with or without anything Trump does.<br />\n<br />\nChinese economy is a giant PONZI scheme.<br />\n<br />\nChina is about to set the world record with a $9 trillion Ponzi.<br />\n<br />\nChinese have a middle-class of several hundred million people with a high propensity to save. Most Chinese don\u2019t get to invest overseas, so they are limited to real estate, gold and local investment products, mostly sold through banks.<br />\n<br />\nWhen customers go into a bank, they are offered a standard bank deposit paying about 2%, or a \u201cwealth management product,\u201d (WMP) that pays about 8%.<br />\n<br />\nWMPs are something like the collateralized debt obligations (CDOs) that brought down Lehman Brothers.<br />\n<br />\nMany customers naturally take the 8% return and invest in bank-managed WMPs. Customers believe the WMPs are guaranteed by the bank or the government. They\u2019re not \u2014 WMPs are just unsecured investments.<br />\n<br />\nWMP\u2019s IN CHINA IS THE GREATEST PONZI SCHEME EVER ON THIS PLANET\u2014DEVISED BY MAD COMMIES. IN POWER.<br />\n<br />\nChinese banks use sales of WMPs to invest in the riskiest development projects and state-owned enterprises (SOEs) on the edge of bankruptcy.<br />\n<br />\nThese institutions behind these projects, financed by the original WMPs, cannot repay them. So most of the WMPs will never be repaid.<br />\n<br />\nBanks rely on sales of new WMPs to redeem the old ones at maturity. Today, when a customer wants his money back, the bank sells a new WMP, and uses that money to cash out the redeeming customer. The new investor steps into the shoes of the old with the same bad underlying investment.<br />\n<br />\nWhat happens when everyone wants his money back at once, or new customers just stop investing?<br />\n<br />\nThis is how Ponzi schemes always collapse<br />\n<br />\nPonzi schemes are a kind of pyramid scheme which operate on the \"rob Peter to pay Paul\" principle.<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: red;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2013/03/amway-merchants-of-pipe-dreams-capt.html</span><br />\n<br />\nWith the promise of large returns as bait, the fraudster takes in money from new investors and uses it to pay off the earlier investors until no more new recruits can be found and the whole scheme collapses, with the newest investors losing everything.<br />\n<br />\nIn Bernard 'Bernie' Madoff's case, he told FBI agents he had been paying investors \"with money that wasn't there\". Regulatory filings show he managed money for hedge funds, banks and wealthy individuals.<br />\n<br />\nBernard Lawrence \"Bernie\" Madoff is an American financier who executed the largest Ponzi scheme in history, defrauding thousands of investors of 65 billion USD over the course of at least 4 decades..<br />\n<br />\nWhen clients wished to redeem their investments, Madoff funded the payouts with new capital, which he attracted through a reputation for unbelievable returns and grooming his victims by earning their trust. Madoff created a front of respectability and generosity, wooing investors through his charitable work<br />\n<br />\nWhile Madoff was sentenced to 150 years and prison and ordered to forfeit $170 million in assets<br />\n<br />\nCONTINUED TO 2--</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" id=\"bc_0_220BR\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 36px; margin-top: 1em;\">\n<span id=\"bc_0_220b+seedDcD\" kind=\"d\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"comment-thread inline-thread\" id=\"bc_0_221T\" kind=\"t\" style=\"background-color: #eeeeee; margin: 8px 0px; padding: 0.5em 1em;\" t=\"0\" u=\"0\">\n<ol class=\"thread-chrome thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_221TC\" style=\"list-style-type: none; padding: 0px;\" unselectable=\"on\"><div style=\"zoom: 1;\" unselectable=\"on\">\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<li class=\"comment\" id=\"bc_0_221B\" kind=\"b\" style=\"border-bottom: 0px; margin: 0px 0px 16px; padding: 16px 0px 0px;\"><div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"float: left; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n<span id=\"bc_0_220b+seedDcD\" kind=\"d\"></span></div>\n<span id=\"bc_0_220b+seedDcD\" kind=\"d\">\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c6242505420083971584\" style=\"margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_221M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2017/11/blockchain-smart-contracts-hashgraphs.html?showComment=1509819165751#c6242505420083971584\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">November 4, 2017 at 11:42 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_221MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nCONTINUED FROM 1-<br />\n<br />\nPonzi schemes are run by a central operator, who uses the money from new, incoming investors to pay off the promised returns to older ones. This makes the operation seem profitable and legitimate, even though no actual profit is being made. Meanwhile, the person behind the scheme pockets the extra money or uses it to expand the operation.<br />\n<br />\nTo avoid having too many investors reclaim their \"profits,\" Ponzi schemes encourage them to stay in the game and earn even more money. The \"investing strategies\" used are vague and/or secretive, which schemers claim is to protect their business. Then all they need to do is tell investors how much they are making periodically, without actually providing any real returns.<br />\n<br />\nIn Madoff's case, things began to deteriorate after clients requested a total of $7 billion back in returns. Unfortunately for Madoff, he only had $200 million left to give.<br />\n<br />\nMadoff sat on the board of National Association of Securities Dealers and advised the Securities and Exchange Commission on trading securities. It was easy to believe this 70-year-old industry veteran knew exactly what he was doing.<br />\n<br />\nMadoff really only made off with $20 billion, even though on paper he cheated clients out of $65 billion<br />\n<br />\nPresident Xi had been converted by Chinese slave media to be a second Mao, only to sustain the great Chinese Ponzi. Five months ago, Forsea Insurance, one of China\u2019s largest insurers, warned that there would be \u201cmass defaults and social unrest\u201d if it was prevented from selling new WMPs to meet payouts<br />\n<br />\nSix months ago , Minsheng Bank, China\u2019s largest private bank, committed a RMB 3 bn fraud by selling non-existent WMPs<br />\n<br />\nWe are in the last lap of the Chinese Ponzi as, piece by piece, the whole decrepit system is being exposed. In the end, it will boil down to how many trillions of RMB the PBoC needs to print to make the banks and their shadow banking relatives whole.<br />\n<br />\nIN THE CASE OF PRESIDENT XI\u2014HE HOPES TO DIE OF NATURAL CAUSES BEFORE HIS IS HUNG FOR MASTERMINDING AND CONTINUING WITH THE CHINESE PONZI.<br />\n<br />\nWHEN BITCOIN AND BLOCKCHAIN CHINESE MINING BOMBS SOONER THAN LATER., PRESIDENT XI WILL BE UP SHIT FUCKIN\u2019 CREEK WITHOUT A PADDLE WHEN THE MINSKY MOMEMT SHIT HITS THE FAN<br />\n<br />\n\"Minsky moment\", refers to a sudden collapse in asset prices after long periods of growth, sparked by debt or currency pressures.<br />\n<br />\nTotal borrowing had ballooned to more than 300% of the size of the Chinese economy, up from 158 % in 2008. The overall debt burden at almost 3.6 times the annual economic output.<br />\n<br />\nAs funding costs for Chinese banks have risen, they have been forced to compensate by placing more money in the shadow banking sector, with all the risks that entails (i.e. leverage and risky assets).<br />\n<br />\nTo balance out these rising costs, banks have been placing more of their money with so-called nonbank financial institutions\u2014the likes of trust companies, funds and securities companies\u2014that offer high returns from investing in various markets, from bonds to stocks and commodities.<br />\n<br />\nChina\u2019s shadow banks are, in part, engaged in Ponzi schemes, for example in the 4.2 Trillion Wealth Management Products (WMP) sector.<br />\n<br />\nPOOR PRESIDENT XI\u2014THROW A CHAPATTI IN HIS GENERAL DIRECTION.<br />\n<span style=\"color: red;\"><br />http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2017/07/can-china-afford-war-with-india-come-on.html<br /><br />http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2017/08/can-china-afford-war-with-india-come-on.html</span><br />\n<br />\nCapt Ajit vadakayil<br />\n..</div>\n</div>\n</span></li>\n<span id=\"bc_0_220b+seedDcD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<span id=\"bc_0_220b+seedDcD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></ol>\n<span id=\"bc_0_220b+seedDcD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<span id=\"bc_0_220b+seedDcD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; max-width: 36px;\" /></div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c2084651867336847165\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_119M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2017/11/comments-overflow-for-inoperative-load.html?showComment=1510668772254#c2084651867336847165\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">November 14, 2017 at 7:42 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_119MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nThe total debt in the U.S. and China as a percent of economic output is greater than 300%.<br />\n<br />\nUSA is 20.4 trillion USD in debt<br />\n<br />\nChina\u2019s debt-to-GDP ratio has continued to grow as the MAD commies in power don\u2019t have a clue.<br />\n<br />\nIndia is the only roaring economy on this planet<br />\n<br />\nA debt-infused crisis in China would reverberate loudly around the world's economy and its financial markets. Few investors would be unaffected by a financial crisis in China.<br />\n<br />\nProperty development is a big part of China\u2019s rising debt burden. China is guilty of mass producing fishing boats which will never catch a fish in its lifetime ( just a equivalent to understand )<br />\n<br />\nChina's property developers owe banks more than US$440 billion.<br />\n<br />\nChinese banks are being forced to curb lending to home buyers. No lending is allowed at all to buyers who are not \u201clocally qualified\u201d.<br />\n<br />\nFor example, buyers must have been paying local taxes or local pension plans for at least one year (and in some cities five years) in order to qualify for bank financing for a home.<br />\n<br />\nPolicy makers understand that there is a big need for housing as new middle class people flood to the cities. But more importantly, the need for affordable housing is becoming much more central to policy.<br />\n<br />\nThe rising debt has brought with it rising non-performing loans (NPLs) and the risk of potential major problems for the country's banking system.<br />\n<br />\nChinese banks are looking down the barrel of a staggering $1.85 trillion worth of losses<br />\n<br />\nChina is approaching the Minsky moment that precipitated the US financial crisis of 2008.<br />\n<br />\nCompanies borrow only as much as they can repay from cash flow. But as asset prices rise, they are joined by more speculative borrowers, who can cover interest payments but count on capital gains to repay their principal.<br />\n<br />\nFinally the system enters full-on bubble mode, propelled by \u201cPonzi\u201d borrowers, who can afford neither interest nor principal payments and rely on excessively easy credit and ever-rising asset prices just to stay afloat.<br />\n<br />\nAlas, credit-fuelled asset bubbles can\u2019t last forever. Sooner or later the Minsky moment arrives.<br />\n<br />\nChinese debt has grown rapidly, and much faster than the economy, from around 140 % cent of gross domestic product 10 years ago to somewhere around 310 % today.<br />\n<br />\nMUCH OF THE BORROWING THROUGH CHINA\u2019S SHADOW BANKING MARKET RESEMBLES CLASSIC SPECULATIVE BEHAVIOUR.<br />\n<br />\nANECDOTES ABOUND OF INVESTORS LEVERAGING FAR BEYOND THEIR MEANS EVEN TO PAY INTEREST IN ORDER TO PILE INTO FAST-RISING PROPERTY MARKETS \u2013 TYPICAL PONZI BEHAVIOUR.<br />\n<br />\nCHINESE NON-FINANCIAL CORPORATE DEBT NOW ACCOUNTS FOR AROUND A THIRD OF GLOBAL NON-FINANCIAL CORPORATE DEBT!<br />\n<br />\nCurrently the total global debt bubble is over $220 trillion, with little sign of it slowing.<br />\n<br />\nThe economy of most western nations is a house of cards -ready to come down anytime.<br />\n<br />\nWhen this happens only Jew Rothschild will laugh all the way to his own bank<br />\n<br />\ncapt ajit vadakayil<br />\n..</div>\n</div>\n<br /></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<ol id=\"bc_0_138TB\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; float: left; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n<img src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-57G2xiZ-5tM/WJwrrVpmOmI/AAAAAAABQqo/-9wsspdm4RAiWSVRYXpBpkgoVBQdEyLRQCK4B/s35/*\" style=\"border: 1px solid rgb(238, 238, 238); max-width: 36px;\" /></div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c4047676304203476716\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_174M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2017/11/urumi-invincible-kalari-sword-wootz.html?showComment=1511174048584#c4047676304203476716\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">November 20, 2017 at 4:04 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_174MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\n<br />\nhttps://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/india-holds-145-billion-of-us-govt-bonds/articleshow/61721513.cms<br />\n<br />\nTHE CHART GIVEN IN TIMES OF INDIA POST IS WRONG--<br />\n<br />\nTreasuries held by China slipped by $19.7bn to $1.18tn, while US sovereign notes and bonds owned by Japan dropped by $5.7bn to $1.1tn in September 2017...<br />\n<br />\nChina remains the biggest foreign holder of U.S. Treasuries, ahead of Japan<br />\n<br />\nIn 1986 when China opened its bamboo doors -- on the ship I gave advances to my crew for shopping in Renminbi .<br />\n<br />\nMy crew could not use this money in the local market which used yuan - they had to use Renminbi in special shops meant for foreigners where prices were high. Yuan purchase in the local marker was DIRT CHEAP.<br />\n<br />\nWe used to change our Renminbi with local yuan from shipyard workers and then go ashore and have a nice time . Even today nobody can explain the difference on the internet. I experienced it-so I know.<br />\n<br />\nOverall foreign holdings of US Treasury securities is $6.3235 trillion<br />\n<br />\nTHE YIELD OF A US TREASURY BOND IS VERY LOW AND IS NOT RISK FREE ANYMORE<br />\n<br />\nUSA IS 20.5 TRILLION USD IN DEBT<br />\n<br />\nUS GOVT HAS TO TAKE ON NEW DEBTS BEFORE PAYING OFF OLD DEBTS -- EVEN IF BONDS MATURE<br />\n<br />\nIt's possible, at least in theory, that Congress could refuse to approve any new debt, triggering a default. This is more important in the modern scenario where USA is armtwisting India regarding our ties with Iran and North Korea.<br />\n<br />\nChina is a manufacturing hub with an export-driven economy highly dependent on exports to the U.S.<br />\n<br />\nChinese exporters receive U.S. dollars for the goods they sell to the U.S., but they need renminbi to pay their workers. They sell dollars to get RMB, increasing the dollar supply and raising demand for RMB.<br />\n<br />\nChina wants to maintain export-led growth, so its RMB must be lower in value than the dollar so prices can be cheaper.<br />\n<br />\nChina\u2019s central bank buys excess U.S. dollars from exporters and gives them RMB to keep the dollar rate higher. Otherwise, the RMB would appreciate, making Chinese exports costlier, leading to unemployment as exports slow.<br />\n<br />\nBut by keeping the RMB low, the dollar piles high among China\u2019s forex reserves. China puts its trillions of dollars in forex reserves in the safest investment it can find\u2014U.S. Treasury securities. This means China is making loans to the U.S. so the U.S. can keep buying China\u2019s goods.<br />\n<br />\nBoth nations benefit. China gets a huge market for its products, and the U.S. pays economical prices for China\u2019s goods.<br />\n<br />\nIf China offloaded some of its U.S. debt, an excess supply of U.S. dollars would reduce the dollar\u2019s value and make the RMB appreciate. China\u2019s products would cost more, ending China\u2019s pricing advantage. China\u2019s trade surplus would then become a deficit, something no export-driven economy wants.<br />\n<br />\nChina has been running a big trade surplus with the US since 1985. This means that China sells more goods and services to the US, than the US sells to China.<br />\n<br />\nChinese exporters receive US dollars for their goods sold to the US, but they need Renminbi (RMB or Yuan) to pay their workers and store money locally. They sell the dollars they receive through exports to get RMB, which increases the USD supply and raises demand for RMB.<br />\n<br />\nChina wants to keep its goods competitive in the international markets, and that cannot happen if the RMB appreciates.<br />\n<br />\nCONTINUED TO 2</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" id=\"bc_0_174BR\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; display: inline-block;\"><span class=\"thread-count\" id=\"bc_0_173TN\">\n</span></span><br />\n</span><br />\n<ol class=\"thread-chrome thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_173TC\" style=\"list-style-type: none; padding: 0px;\"><span id=\"bc_0_174b+seed7jdD\" kind=\"d\">\n<li class=\"comment\" id=\"bc_0_173B\" kind=\"b\" style=\"border-bottom: 0px; margin: 0px 0px 16px; padding: 16px 0px 0px;\"><div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"float: left; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n<img src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-57G2xiZ-5tM/WJwrrVpmOmI/AAAAAAABQqo/-9wsspdm4RAiWSVRYXpBpkgoVBQdEyLRQCK4B/s35/*\" style=\"border: 1px solid rgb(238, 238, 238); max-width: 36px;\" /></div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c1808557508128619952\" style=\"margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_173M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2017/11/urumi-invincible-kalari-sword-wootz.html?showComment=1511174079313#c1808557508128619952\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">November 20, 2017 at 4:04 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_173MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nCONTINUED FROM 1-<br />\n<br />\nWere China to suddenly unload its reserve holdings, its currency\u2019s exchange rate would rise, making Chinese exports more expensive in foreign markets. As such, China\u2019s holdings of American debt do not provide China with undue economic influence over the United States.<br />\n<br />\nTo avoid inflation, the Chinese central bank removes this incoming foreign currency by purchasing foreign assets\u2014including U.S. Treasury bonds\u2014in a process called \u201csterilization.\u201d<br />\n<br />\nThis system has the disadvantage of generating unnecessarily low returns on investment: by relying on FDI, Chinese firms borrow from abroad at high interest rates, while China continues to lend to foreign entities at low interest rates.<br />\n<br />\nThis system also compels China to purchase foreign assets, including safe, convenient U.S. debt.<br />\n<br />\nChina lends to the United States by buying Treasuries because it has few other options, not as some kind of favor.<br />\n<br />\nAmerican companies, for the most part, have to pay for their Chinese imports in Chinese currency, just as Chinese companies buying from the U.S. need to pay in dollars.<br />\n<br />\nThe dollars spent purchasing Renminbi end up in the hands of the People\u2019s Bank of China<br />\n<br />\nOwnership of US debt is not a currency move, it's a function of trade flows.<br />\n<br />\nChina and Japan own US debt because they sell a lot of stuff to the US and those dollars get put back into Treasuries.<br />\n<br />\nThe rest of the $20 trillion US national debt is owned by either the American people or by the U.S. government itself.<br />\n<br />\nLong-term, China wants the yuan to replace the U.S. dollar as the world's global currency.( note yuan and RMB is same thing )<br />\n<br />\nCapt ajit vadakayil<br />\n..</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n</span></ol>\n<span id=\"bc_0_174b+seed7jdD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<span id=\"bc_0_174b+seed7jdD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; float: left; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n<img src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-DUOJiRC5obw/UwiDtflONuI/AAAAAAAAppU/hpxnNJK2CIw/s113/*\" style=\"border: 1px solid rgb(238, 238, 238); max-width: 36px;\" /></div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c3765020939355847578\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_295M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2016/06/gpi-dog-shall-wag-gdp-tail-not-vice.html?showComment=1511597089627#c3765020939355847578\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">November 25, 2017 at 1:34 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_295MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nhttp://www.news18.com/news/world/uk-drops-out-of-worlds-top-5-economies-only-one-spot-above-india-now-1586931.html<br />\n<br />\nIF YOU KNOW \"REAL\" ECONOMICS, INDIA IS NO 3 ECONOMY ON THIS PLANET<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: red;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/06/gpi-dog-shall-wag-gdp-tail-not-vice.html</span><br />\n<br />\nG7 NATIONS ARE BEGGARS<br />\n<br />\nUSA IS 20.6 TRILLION USD IN DEBT<br />\n<br />\nGross national debt in the US IS 112% of GDP. In the US, total debt to the private non-financial sector has ballooned to $ 30.1 trillion..<br />\n<br />\nEU debt is 182 % of GDP<br />\n<br />\nJapanese debt as percent of GDP is 171% of GDP.<br />\n<br />\nCHINAs DEBT IS 320% OF GDP<br />\n<br />\nINDIA IS THE ONLY ROARING ECONOMY ON THIS PLANET<br />\n<br />\nCHINESE ECONOMY IS MANAGED BY MAD MEN<br />\n<br />\nChina has a humongous shadow banking sector. Shadow banking refers to activities performed by financial firms outside the formal banking sector, and therefore subject to lower levels of regulatory oversight and higher risks. Such activities are off the balance sheets due to accounting practices.<br />\n<br />\nShadow banking in the Chinese economy WILL eventually lead to a financial crisis when the bubble pops.<br />\n<br />\n<br />\nGDP growth is not the same as economic growth. Consider two factories that cost the same to build and operate. If the first factory produces useful goods, and the second produces unwanted ones that pile up as inventory, only the first boosts the underlying economy.<br />\n<br />\nCHINA HAS BEEN BUILDING MILLIONS OF FISHING BOATS AND PLACING IT IN THE DESERT , WHICH WILL NEVER CATCH A SINGLE FISH ( EQUIVALENT )<br />\n<br />\nBad debt is not written down and the Chinese commie government is not subject to hard budget constraints.<br />\n<br />\nAnyone who believes there has been a significant amount of wasted investment in China must accept that reported GDP growth overstates the real increase in wealth by the failure to recognise the associated bad debt. Were it correctly written down, Chinese GDP growth would fall below 2.9 %.<br />\n<br />\nChina\u2019s growth miracle has already run out of steam. It is only by allowing debt to surge that the country is able to meet its GDP targets..<br />\n<br />\nPiling up unsold and unsaleable goods or building ghost cities , subterranean tunnels and empty airports may boost GDP in an economy whose financial system does not recognise bad debt, but it does not measure its performance.<br />\n<br />\nChina is about to set the world record with a $9.2 trillion Ponzi. Most Chinese don\u2019t get to invest overseas, so they are limited to real estate, gold and local investment products, mostly sold through banks.<br />\n<br />\nWhen customers go into a bank, they are offered a standard bank deposit paying about 2%, or a \u201cwealth management product,\u201d (WMP) that pays about 8%.<br />\n<br />\nWMPs are something like the collateralized debt obligations (CDOs) that brought down Lehman Brothers.<br />\n<br />\nMany customers naturally take the 8% return and invest in bank-managed WMPs. Customers believe the WMPs are guaranteed by the bank or the government. They\u2019re not \u2014 WMPs are just unsecured investments.<br />\n<br />\nWMP\u2019s have been described by the former Chairman of the Bank of China as the greatest Ponzi scheme in history.<br />\n<br />\nThe banks use sales of WMPs to invest in the riskiest development projects and state-owned enterprises (SOEs) on the edge of bankruptcy.<br />\n<br />\nThese institutions behind these projects, financed by the original WMPs, cannot repay them. So most of the WMPs will never be repaid.<br />\n<br />\nBanks rely on sales of new WMPs to redeem the old ones at maturity. Today, when a customer wants his money back, the bank sells a new WMP, and uses that money to cash out the redeeming customer. The new investor steps into the shoes of the old with the same bad underlying investment.<br />\n<br />\n<br />\nCONTINUED TO 2--</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" id=\"bc_0_295BR\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; But, these are not normal corporations as understood in the U.S. These are mostly state-owned enterprises, controlled by the commie government.<br />\n<br />\nThat means they may have to be bailed-out by the government when the system finally crumbles.<br />\n<br />\nMuch of this debt is denominated in U.S. dollars so the situation is made even worse by the strong dollar and the global dollar shortage. Both of those factors make dollar-denominated debt much harder to repay.<br />\n<br />\nThe debt system is propped up \u2014 for now \u2014 by more debt and dishonest accounting. If the banks were forced to write-down bad loans, the system would have collapsed a long time ago.<br />\n<br />\nChina is faced with a mountain of unpayable debt, weaker growth, and a stronger dollar that will make the debt even harder to repay. The Chinese credit bubble has only one feasible solution, China must use its hard currency reserves to bail-out the entire banking and SOE sector and try to start over with a relatively clean balance sheet.<br />\n<br />\nThe problem is that the reserves needed for a bail-out are evaporating and liquid reserves will dwindle by the end of 2017.<br />\n<br />\nWHEN THE CHINESE BUBBLE BURSTS debt to GDP is now more than 380 % -- China's debt is very high by international standards.<br />\n<br />\nChinese corporate debt is currently at 181 percent of GDP<br />\n<br />\nThe MAD commies who run China do NOT understand the meaning of DEBT FUELED GROWTH.<br />\n<br />\nHigh levels of corporate, government and household debt have undermined China\u2019s financial stability.<br />\n<br />\nChinese banking sector is facing an imminent blowout.<br />\n<br />\nChina's unregulated and growing SHADOW BANKING sector is the main driver of the Chinese credit boom<br />\n<br />\nCredit growth is an important indicator of future financial distress, because lending standards often fall in the rush to make more loans<br />\n<br />\nThe existence of \u2018shadow banking' loans outside the formal banking system, makes it challenging to assess the scale of private sector debt, and China's lagging regulatory system, which mirrors the slow reforms of its legal system, raises doubts over whether there is sufficient capacity to prevent and address a potential financial crisis<br />\n<br />\nChina's loss-making often state-owned firms have come to be known as 'zombie' companies and banks and investors fund many of them as if they would not be allowed to fail.<br />\n<br />\nThe problem lies in high growth targets, which incentivize local commie governments to extend credit and protect failing companies<br />\n<br />\nThe MAD commie government had been prioritizing SOCIAL STABILITY in the near-term\u2014they to rely on credit expansion to continue financing firms even when they are not viable at all.<br />\n<br />\nThe MAD comies have introduced increasingly complex and opaque financial products a, Banks are encouraging excessive risk-taking by compensating investors for losses posed additional risks<br />\n<br />\nThese ignorant commies are hell bent of showcasing GDP growth\u2014which is NOT real economics<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: red;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2016/06/gpi-dog-shall-wag-gdp-tail-not-vice.html</span><br />\n<br />\nStandard &amp; Poor's in September 2017, cut China's credit rating. Current Chinese growth is less than 4.2%.. The economy grew 6.7 percent last year ( HYPED UP ), --still a 26-year low..<br />\n<br />\nThe Chinese government is treading a thin line between deleveraging and keeping its debt-fueled economy humming.<br />\n<br />\n<br />\nChina has pledged to switch course from a prolonged, debt-fueled investment binge to higher quality and more balanced growth, as signaled by President Xi Jinping during an agenda-setting Communist Party Congress in October 2017\u2014 BALLS he can do it.<br />\n<br />\nA statement after the Politburo meeting listed control of the \u201cmacro-leverage ratio,\u201d or Chinese debt-to-GDP ratio, as a major piece of the Commie government\u2019s effort to fend off risks next year. That contrasted with its statement ahead of last year\u2019s economic conference, which described debt reduction as a key task.<br />\n<br />\nChina has NO choice but to unleash the overdrive on debt because of fears of growing trade wars with the US<br />\n<br />\nMore than 58% of new bank loans are flowing into the real-estate market, not to areas of the economy that can improve the country\u2019s competitiveness. The property market, including construction and home furnishings, accounts for a third of overall growth.<br />\n<br />\nChina is looking for ways to rein in housing speculation without setting off a housing crash that could torpedo the economy.<br />\n<br />\nChinese gross domestic product (GDP) is forecasted to end 2017 at around $12 trillion, while the total debt to GDP is more than 380 %..<br />\n<br />\nCONTINUED TO 2--</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" id=\"bc_0_22BR\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; At this stage, in our view the China credit bubble is as ripe as it gets to burst<br />\n<br />\nChina is simply in the biggest credit bubble ever and it translates to the biggest currency bubble ever given the sheer magnitude of yuan denominated credit when converted to dollars at the current exchange rate<br />\n<br />\nChina is trying to attract foreign capital into its credit markets but supply is much greater than demand.
