, &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif;\"><span style=\"font-size: 18.6667px;\">The Thin Red Line was aa movie too paralyzingly high-minded to connect with chootiya HILLY HILLY audiences</span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif;\"><span style=\"font-size: 18.6667px;\"><br /></span></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif;\"><span style=\"font-size: 18.6667px;\">Japan sent a total of 33,000 soldiers to Guadalcanal, of which only &nbsp;8,000 returned. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span><br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif;\"><span style=\"font-size: 18.6667px;\"><a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-6ON4wwUPkls/WYMrUmFXvNI/AAAAAAABVPk/eNKhdD-2t40t05ytLQ5IrRAAyw3Yu1klgCLcBGAs/s1600/ijmage.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"400\" data-original-width=\"640\" height=\"400\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-6ON4wwUPkls/WYMrUmFXvNI/AAAAAAABVPk/eNKhdD-2t40t05ytLQ5IrRAAyw3Yu1klgCLcBGAs/s640/ijmage.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></span></span></div>\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif;\"><span style=\"font-size: 18.6667px;\">80% &nbsp;of the 25,000 dead were noncombat fatalities &nbsp;. &nbsp;Lot of them ( dying of Malaria ) &nbsp;went as food in their own fellow Jap soldiers stomachs .</span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif;\"><span style=\"font-size: 18.6667px;\"><br /></span></span>\n<br />\n<div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-org2XaVXDmU/WYMpmevAriI/AAAAAAABVPU/kYjsJwjxIH8ovTK1pAtCNvl7vxKKRBIoQCLcBGAs/s1600/becae5dc8c223e9f3e00a61169ec2b52b--guadalcanal-campaign-concentration-camps.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"939\" data-original-width=\"736\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-org2XaVXDmU/WYMpmevAriI/AAAAAAABVPU/kYjsJwjxIH8ovTK1pAtCNvl7vxKKRBIoQCLcBGAs/s1600/becae5dc8c223e9f3e00a61169ec2b52b--guadalcanal-campaign-concentration-camps.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Malick, who lives in\nTexas, doesn't play those quintessential KOSHER Hollywood games. &nbsp;&nbsp;Maybe that's part of the reason this Harvard-\nand Oxford-educated recluse directed the justly acclaimed Badlands (1973) and\nDays of Heaven (1978) and then fell off the face of the earth \u2014 that's industry\nspeak for not making movies.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">After directing two of\nthe most enduring, visionary films of the '70s, Badlands (1973) and Days Of\nHeaven (1978), reclusive iconoclast Terrence Malick dropped out of sight\naltogether, and in the 20 years since, his standing in critical circles has\nballooned to mythic proportions.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In 1993, four years\nafter the United States National Film Registry was established, Badlands was\nselected for preservation by the Library of Congress for being\n\"culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant\".&nbsp;&nbsp; Terrence Malick's debut was a masterful\nslice of American cinema, rife with the visual poetry<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In 2007 Days of Heaven\nwas selected for preservation in the National Film Registry by the Library of\nCongress as being \"culturally, historically, or aesthetically\nsignificant\". It continues to appear in polls of the best films ever made<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">One of the cinema's\ngreat disappearing acts came to a close with the release of The Thin Red Line\nin late 1998<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hollywood had changed\nmuch since Malick had last made a film; with major corporations buying the\ngreat studios and blockbuster filmmaking a priority, visionary films like those\nMalick had made previously were difficult to come by.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It took long\nnegotiations for a team of producers to get Malick back behind the camera.\nHollywood had gone through drastic changes while he walked the earth for twenty\nyears, and the new corporate chiefs preferred market-friendly blockbusters ( for\ndimwits ) to offbeat art pictures. This is a thinkin\u2019 man\u2019s war movie. None of\nthe past hyped up commie and perverted deans in FTII Pune will even understand\nit.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In 1988, Geisler and\nJohn Roberdeau met with Malick in Paris about writing and directing a movie\nbased on D. M. Thomas' 1981 novel The White Hotel. Malick declined, but told\nthem that he would be willing instead to write either an adaptation of James\nJones' The Thin Red Line. The producers paid Malick $250,000 to write a\nscreenplay.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Malick began adapting\nThe Thin Red Line on January 1, 1989. Five months later, the producers received\nhis first draft, which was 300 pages long. According to an article in\nEntertainment Weekly, they gained the director's confidence by \"catering\nto his every whim<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;20th Century Fox agreed to put up $39 million\nof the budget with the stipulation that Malick cast five movie stars from a\nlist of 10 who were interested.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In 1995, once word went\nout that Malick was making another movie after many years, numerous actors\napproached him, flooding the casting directors until they had to announce they\nwouldn't be accepting more requests. Some A-list actors including Brad Pitt, Al\nPacino, Gary Oldman, and George Clooney offered to work for a fraction and some\neven offered to work for free.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bruce Willis even went as far as offering to pay\nfor first-class tickets for the casting crew, to get a few lines for the movie.\n<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In 1996 he had a clause\ninserted in his contract barring the producers from the set\u2014Malick would not be\narmtwisted into anything</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Malick's reputation and\nworking methods commanded great respect among the actors<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Producers Robert\nMichael Geisler and John Roberdeau fell out with director Terrence Malick\nduring pre-production.&nbsp;&nbsp; By the time they\nwere filming, their relationship had so deteriorated that Malick barred them\nfrom visiting the set.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-aYaiHy2cSg4/WYMr0fIdVWI/AAAAAAABVPw/hnThV0111aMN-h2s4QZCrcrmYWod-hnHgCLcBGAs/s1600/582f58bl53c61d.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"264\" data-original-width=\"326\" height=\"518\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-aYaiHy2cSg4/WYMr0fIdVWI/AAAAAAABVPw/hnThV0111aMN-h2s4QZCrcrmYWod-hnHgCLcBGAs/s640/582f58bl53c61d.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Prior to the film's\nrelease, producers Robert Michael Geisler and John Roberdeau allegedly violated\na confidentiality clause they had signed by giving an interview to Vanity Fair\nabout their long involvement with Terrence Malick and the film. Malick was\nupset by this.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Geisler and Roberdeau had to sign another agreement stating they\nwould not attend the Oscars ceremony. If they violated that agreement, their\nnames would be stripped from the film and video credits.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-cecIBFVD_xk/WYM9gh76VZI/AAAAAAABVQc/XYufqW-cS0IEVTwBPLUfSaLqbJtvql3DACLcBGAs/s1600/terrence-maklick-the_thin_red_line.png\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"680\" data-original-width=\"1600\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-cecIBFVD_xk/WYM9gh76VZI/AAAAAAABVQc/XYufqW-cS0IEVTwBPLUfSaLqbJtvql3DACLcBGAs/s1600/terrence-maklick-the_thin_red_line.png\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The movie was almost\nnot made. Sony Pictures dropped plans to produce it because of fears that it\ncouldn't be made for its then $45-million budget. Fortunately, Fox Pictures\ncame to the rescue by providing most of the cash.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Malick\u2019s&nbsp; film considers the war that exists between\nearthly and metaphysical ideals, between existence and transcendence, between\nacceptance and searching.. The film\u2019s philosophy comes mainly through the\nvoice-overs, which spend more time asking questions than propounding answers.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The most beautifully\nshot war film ever contrasts with the horror of war in each soldier. The film\nexplores the human condition and gives a sense of the differences each soldier\nhad towards the war itself..&nbsp;</span><br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-3gxKnFRTclI/WYMrekrZ6LI/AAAAAAABVPo/R9b-WG3Fuog1vMBLGPoAssmpbrG6xHN8ACLcBGAs/s1600/3d192416f0bf3dk8a7eb7684cc0f9768a--japan-surrenders-marshall-islands.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"577\" data-original-width=\"736\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-3gxKnFRTclI/WYMrekrZ6LI/AAAAAAABVPo/R9b-WG3Fuog1vMBLGPoAssmpbrG6xHN8ACLcBGAs/s1600/3d192416f0bf3dk8a7eb7684cc0f9768a--japan-surrenders-marshall-islands.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Malick's poetic and philosophical language turns his\nsoldiers into soul-searching poets<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The story jumps between\nits five main characters and at least a dozen minor ones<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are them sweet\nmoments when the internal monologues dovetail into dialogue and vice versa-- of\nspiritual self-interrogation<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The cinematography by\nJohn Toll is striking, capturing a number of memorable images, such as the\ndeath throes of an injured bird, dogs feeding on the remains of the\nrecently-deceased, and the partially-buried face of a dead Japanese soldier.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-ALQSbPn-cWs/WYMrqtP4PzI/AAAAAAABVPs/Win0OgJ0Y9gx5ZBaCUxd5lfgWOhLJAd7wCLcBGAs/s1600/A_further_indication_that_not_all_Japanese_fight_to_the_death_is_this_kkbag_of_221_Nip_prisoners_of_war._Sprawled_on..._-_NARA_-_513225.tif.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"523\" data-original-width=\"652\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-ALQSbPn-cWs/WYMrqtP4PzI/AAAAAAABVPs/Win0OgJ0Y9gx5ZBaCUxd5lfgWOhLJAd7wCLcBGAs/s1600/A_further_indication_that_not_all_Japanese_fight_to_the_death_is_this_kkbag_of_221_Nip_prisoners_of_war._Sprawled_on..._-_NARA_-_513225.tif.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Like the thematic\nundercurrent of the film, Malick constantly juxtaposes images of tranquility\nand destruction: a bearded local passes by the heavily-armed Charlie Company in\nthe jungle and pays them no mind, or the serene image of a sea of tall grass is\nshattered by the life-and-death struggle between the battling armies.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Thin Red Line\"\nis the type of film that polarizes its audience\u2014the intelligentsia versus the\nmorons .. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">These peabrained morons\nleft the movie hall when there was 30% still to go.&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">For them this stay in the theatre was like a\nvisit to the dentist\u2019s clinic</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">DUNKIRK is the shortest\nwar movie ever, while THE THIN RED LINE is the longest<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-eFUBRVgQyF0/WYMo19t268I/AAAAAAABVPM/KIy7_zAsxvoYfBt8iknLA3VtmzbHGtp3QCLcBGAs/s1600/8a77635b7a862533WW91bb8461a3f631d67d.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"369\" data-original-width=\"500\" height=\"472\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-eFUBRVgQyF0/WYMo19t268I/AAAAAAABVPM/KIy7_zAsxvoYfBt8iknLA3VtmzbHGtp3QCLcBGAs/s640/8a77635b7a862533WW91bb8461a3f631d67d.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Malick treats both\nsides in an objective way--some of most shocking and heart wrenching scenes in\nthe movie depict scared Japanese soldiers, they don't differ much from our main\ncharacters, more, they are closer to insanity than the Americans<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-ASjibOZuBBI/WYMop8y4ISI/AAAAAAABVPI/569ENurg6CMBmxUCygb91jphk_nhKCbZwCLcBGAs/s1600/article-2221657-15A0EA2D6000005DC-812_634x812.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"812\" data-original-width=\"634\" height=\"640\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-ASjibOZuBBI/WYMop8y4ISI/AAAAAAABVPI/569ENurg6CMBmxUCygb91jphk_nhKCbZwCLcBGAs/s640/article-2221657-15A0EA2D6000005DC-812_634x812.jpg\" width=\"498\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Thin Red Line is a\nphilosophical treatise, an essay asking many questions (there are no answers\ngiven) regarding the world's evil. The key to understanding is the collective,\nthat is the film's main character.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Terence Malik\u2019s\ncoherent philosophical work is outside of any known genre.&nbsp; It is very rare that Zimmer\u2019s music narrates\na movie, especially in a psychological way--&nbsp;&nbsp;\na score that concentrates on characters' emotions and the overall\nmessage rather than building drama.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-JDJLiD6EB8E/WYMu3yZ42tI/AAAAAAABVQE/lj0fOLUdQroHQ_y47YUQdhUzbMMkKHeigCLcBGAs/s1600/thin_red_oline_jared_leto.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"344\" data-original-width=\"800\" height=\"274\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-JDJLiD6EB8E/WYMu3yZ42tI/AAAAAAABVQE/lj0fOLUdQroHQ_y47YUQdhUzbMMkKHeigCLcBGAs/s640/thin_red_oline_jared_leto.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There are no women as\ncharacters \u2013 even if we glimpse them as dream figures in the minds of the\nsoldiers. It's a deeply mysterious movie, interested in so many things above\nand beyond war, and so beautiful that the sudden sight of bodies and damage\ncome as a surprise.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-twrW6WbEi-I/WYM8XZ4F8dI/AAAAAAABVQU/ejPveUzTSsoxBjQW2F3CH45l3oUg40TggCLcBGAs/s1600/awakening-676386_960_72EW0.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"720\" data-original-width=\"556\" height=\"640\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-twrW6WbEi-I/WYM8XZ4F8dI/AAAAAAABVQU/ejPveUzTSsoxBjQW2F3CH45l3oUg40TggCLcBGAs/s640/awakening-676386_960_72EW0.jpg\" width=\"494\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c5200211907958975982\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_7M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user\" style=\"font-style: normal; text-decoration-line: none;\">August 3, 2017 at 7:47 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_7MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nSir,what is your view on movie \"saving private Ryan\"?</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" id=\"bc_0_7BR\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; margin: 8px 0px; padding: 0.5em 1em;\" t=\"0\" u=\"0\">\n<span id=\"bc_0_7b+seedBIzAD\" kind=\"d\"><span class=\"thread-toggle thread-expanded\" id=\"bc_0_5TT\" kind=\"g\" style=\"cursor: pointer; display: inline-block; padding: 0px;\"><span id=\"bc_0_7b+seedBIzAD\" kind=\"d\">\n<li class=\"comment\" id=\"bc_0_5B\" kind=\"b\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 16px; padding: 16px 0px 8px;\"><div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"float: left; max-width: 36px;\" /></div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c7314883143544206204\" style=\"margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_5M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2017/08/the-thin-red-line-movie-review.html?showComment=1501772623164#c7314883143544206204\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">August 3, 2017 at 8:33 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_5MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">hi gba,</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">The Thin Red Line is better than Steven Spielberg's Saving Private Ryan or even Oliver Stone's Platoon from 1986.</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">Saving Private Ryan succumbs to all of Spielberg\u2019s worst instincts, including his tendency to let the onscreen violence do \u201call the talkin\u2019\u201d.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">Both \"Saving Private Ryan\", and \u201c The Thin Red Line de-romanticizes WW2 and deconstructs it to the brutal reality Unlike Spielberg, Malick takes a more roundabout , but far better way for making this point.</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">Malick knows how to visualize his films in an almost flawless fashion as he plunges his camera into 'The Thin Red Line' and stirs it around until the picture on the screen comes to a boil.</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">For many, the film will be considered too graphic and that's just fine.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">Like 'Saving Private Ryan', it details a mission of American soldiers, this time in the Pacific and details the Guadalcanal conflict which is one of history's most written about events in dealing with the American war effort.</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">The Thin Red line doesn't have that one single talked about scene that will stir up conversation like the opening battle scene in 'Saving Private Ryan'\u2014it is only a series of vignettes strung together</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">Digression: &nbsp; &nbsp;In the Bollywood movie NOORIE , the most talked about thingy was why Poonam THILLONG nay Dhillon tied up her dog\u2014due to which she got raped \u2013TEE HEEEEE .&nbsp;</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: red; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif; font-size: large;\">Don\u2019t tell that to Faye SORPOTEL Dsouza \u2013OK ? &nbsp; Or she will go off on a tangent and <b>THREATHENDENDENN </b>&nbsp;all men with 50% female army at her disposal. TEE HEEEE !</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">Steven Spielberg's \"Saving Private Ryan\" never explored human psyche, though it did explore the rationale behind risking eight lives to free one surviving family member from the dangers on the front. Baap re !</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">\"Saving Private Ryan\" contained graphic battle scenes, the film itself was undoubtedly more mainsteam and accessible for regular HILLY BILLY DUFFER audiences</span><br />\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif; font-size: large;\"><br />\"The Thin Red Line,\" plays like a lyrical poem, much more thought-provoking in its ideas and treatment- &nbsp; it targeted the only intelligentsia. &nbsp; Malick is able to transform everything into a more meaningful tapestry about human nature\u2014this is what film making is all about</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">'Saving Private Ryan.' was embraced lovingly by the usual PEA BRAINED critics\u2014after all it gave the kind of feel good combat picture\u2014with its awe-inspiring technical virtuosity exemplified by the opening D-Day beach sequence.</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">Francois Truffaut once described filmmaking as achieving balance between \"poetry and journalism.\"&nbsp;</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">Steven Spielberg's Saving Private Ryan is arguably a journalistic film: it depicts rather than evokes World War II. It progresses from beginning to end and never strays from its mission.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div style=\"font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; text-align: left;\">\n<span style=\"color: purple; font-size: large;\">The Thin Red Line is the antithesis of Spielberg's movie. It doesn't have a destination.</span><span style=\"color: purple; font-size: large;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div style=\"text-align: left;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">Like the spirit that unifies its soldiers, Malick's filmmaking meanders here and there, picking up what it can, moving on to something else.&nbsp; &nbsp;War thereby becomes a dream-state.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">Malick sacrifices clarity, narrative flow, and maybe even commercial acceptance in the name of sustaining the film's poetic heritage.</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">So so so-- if you want your combat more rah-rah and less think-think, well, there's always 'Saving Private Ryan.'&nbsp;</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">With each year, Spielberg\u2019s war opus looks more dated, encumbered by its legendarily bad framing device and its inability to reconcile the numerous attitudes toward war into one coherent view of it.</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">The Thin Red Line has many narrators, all going through war as this grinding, alienating and dehumanizing experience. They are all trying to save what Private Witt calls \"the spark\" within themselves and remain human in front of this never ending horror.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">Malick does a great job at illustrating their struggle through a series of low, raspy voice-overs as if a character would be talking to himself. They often play while images of wonder (Guadalcanal is a gorgeous place) or horror, while a character is trying to make sense out of the madness.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif;\">CONTINUED TO 2--</span><br />\n<span class=\"comment-actions secondary-text\" id=\"bc_0_5MN\" kind=\"m\" style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif; font-size: 16px;\"><span class=\"item-control blog-admin pid-1783552029\" style=\"display: inline;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" id=\"bc_0_5BR\" style=\"font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 36px; margin-top: 1em;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replybox-single\" id=\"bc_0_5B_box\" style=\"font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 48px; margin-top: 5px;\">\n</div>\n</li>\n<li class=\"comment\" id=\"bc_0_6B\" kind=\"b\" style=\"border-bottom: 0px; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin: 0px 0px 16px; padding: 0.25em 0px 0px;\"><div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"float: left; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n<img src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-57G2xiZ-5tM/WJwrrVpmOmI/AAAAAAABQqo/-9wsspdm4RAiWSVRYXpBpkgoVBQdEyLRQCK4B/s35/*\" style=\"border: 1px solid rgb(238, 238, 238); max-width: 36px;\" /></div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c3046502422985686638\" style=\"margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_6M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2017/08/the-thin-red-line-movie-review.html?showComment=1501772728941#c3046502422985686638\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">August 3, 2017 at 8:35 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_6MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nCONTINUED FROM 1-<br />\n<br />\nThe lean, yet poetic prose of Malick makes it a gripping experience.<br />\n<br />\nIt's a little bit overwhelming sometimes (like all the soldiers were warrior/philosophers), but it works damn fuckin\u2019 well overall.<br />\n<br />\nDuring battle scenes no less terrifying and bewildering than those of Saving Private Ryan, Malick\u2019s impossibly fast dolly shots give way to unrelated close-ups of wildlife, often wildlife caught in the crossfire.<br />\n<br />\nThe only thing romanticized here is the tranquil between battle, and the war serves only to scar this beautiful land and corrupt the human beings who fight it.<br />\n<br />\nIn 1998, there were two \u201cepic\u201d World War II movies, Steven Spielberg\u2019s Saving Private Ryan and Terrence Malick\u2019s The Thin Red Line. Since starring in either men\u2019s movie garners undeniable prestige (with Malick getting the upper hand since it seems he only makes a movie per decade),<br />\n<br />\nHollywood would-be tough guys must have been going crazy trying to decide which movie to join.<br />\n<br />\nSpielberg got Tom Hanks and Malick got, well, everyone else. TEE HEEE !<br />\nThough comparisons to Saving Private Ryan are inevitable, The Thin Red Line's preference for these enigmatic voids separates it from its louder, more outspoken cousin.<br />\n<br />\nMalick doesn't recreate war as Spielberg does; he aint interested in realism.<br />\n<br />\nThe Thin Red Line, like Oliver Stone's Platoon, veils the incoherence of the battlefield with detachment. We somehow remain apart from the action, as if it were a memory.<br />\n<br />\nPutting distance between us and the soldiers, and in certain scenes, between the soldiers and the fighting itself, The Thin Red Line becomes an abstraction of War -- a cinematic ballet of killing , gore and confusion.<br />\n<br />\nOf course as with any good war film, The Thin Red Line contains more than its fair share of action sequences and while they pale in comparison to modern and \u2018realistic\u2019 depictions of battle such as the gruesome scenes of Saving Private Ryan, the film does stand out amongst its contemporaries in terms of violence.<br />\n<br />\nThere are several genuinely harrowing scenes, such as the painfully slow death of a G.I. caught in an explosion, his death assisted by repeated doses of morphine, and Private Doll repeatedly slamming the head of a Japanese soldier to the ground to earn his first kill.<br />\n<br />\nThe Thin Red Line is more of a philosophical study of soldiers at war, so you are almost purposely detached from the characters in order to just focus at the somewhat random thoughts.<br />\n<br />\nUltimately, The Thin Red Line is able to sustain its image of war as absolute hell without making that message seem as hackneyed and worn-out as, in less wizardly hands, it might appear.<br />\n<br />\nUnlike Saving Private Ryan, this film does not introduce itself with a sequence documenting the madness of war, only to cheat itself\u2014and us\u2014by eventually forcing its characters to find meaning in all the madness, to latch onto some cooked-up notion of honor and nobility within what is always and above all a senseless and unruly occurrence.<br />\n<br />\nSpielberg's soldiers continue fighting because by doing so they shall build up their own characters; &nbsp;Malick's bleaker but more honest film insists that battle \"turns men into dogs, poisons the soul,\" and we are at no point asked to determine what any of the protagonists have learned or drawn from their horrific experiences.<br />\n<br />\nThe Thin Red Line made only a fraction of what Steven Spielberg\u2019s Saving Private Ryan made and both films lost to the PATHETIC Shakespeare in Love for the Best Picture Oscar.<br />\n<br />\nJust shows what the KOSHER Oscars are worth<br />\n<br />\nCapt Ajit Vadakayil<br />\n..</div>\n</div>\n</li>\n</span></ol>\n<span id=\"bc_0_7b+seedBIzAD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<span id=\"bc_0_7b+seedBIzAD\" kind=\"d\">\n</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The movie and book ( JAMES JONES 1962 ) reflects that Staros was a\nKOSHER coward ( converted to KOSHER compassionate ) who defies orders from his\nsuperior officer Col Tall.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The soldiers are not\nwell-developed as individual characters. &nbsp;&nbsp;Covered in grime and blood, they look much\nalike, and we strain to hear their names, barked out mostly in one syllable\n(Welsh, Fife, Tall, Witt, Gaff, Bosche, Bell, Keck, Staros). &nbsp;&nbsp;Sometimes during an action we are not sure\nwho we are watching, and have to piece it together afterward<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The characters convey\nthe fears, frustrations, and perils of combat, including Private Bell (Ben\nChaplin) whose deepest wound comes not in battle but in a \"Dear John\"\nletter from his unfaithful adulterous wife; McCron (John Savage) a sergeant who\nis mentally unhinged by the losses of his squad; and Private First Class Doll\n(Dash Mihok) who wants to be a hero.&nbsp;&nbsp; In\nWitt, we have eternal Optimism, the ability to see the good in everything\ndespite the harshest of conditions. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; I want to come back to you the man I was before.\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For their efforts the\nmen are given a week's leave: the airfield where they are based comes under\nenemy artillery bombardment; Bell receives a letter from his wife informing him\nthat she has fallen in love with someone else and wishes to divorce-and this\nshatters him internally--his buddies are celebrating with booze and happy with the contents of their letters from home&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Private Bell is haunted gai by lyrical memories of his wife.
