text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/JDYxmGHMjJo/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/JDYxmGHMjJo?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the movie you have\ncharacters like Nick Nolte\u2019s Lieutenant Colonel Tall asking how many men have to be\nsacrificed to complete the mission. Or &nbsp;Captain Staros, trying to limit\ncasualties to as few as humanly possible because he doesn\u2019t like seeing his men\nget hurt.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">We see a man yank the grass from the soil yelling \u201cThat\u2019s us! That\u2019s\nall that\u2019s left for us!\u201d We see another man pouring dirt all over his face and\nhelmet fearfully murmuring to himself \u201cWe\u2019re dirt. We\u2019re just dirt.\u201d&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Penn\u2019s\nSergeant Welsh at one point says \u201cWhat difference do you think you can make,\none single man in all this madness? If you die, it\u2019s gonna be for nothing.\nThere\u2019s not some other world out there where everything\u2019s gonna be okay.\nThere\u2019s just this world. Just this rock.\u201d<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Private Witt marches to\na different drummer,. His speculative voiceover, frequently framed in\nunanswered questions, contemplates man\u2019s fallen spiritual condition and yearns\nfor communion with the sublime in decidedly poetic cadences: &nbsp;\u201cWhy can\u2019t we stay on the heights, the heights\nwe\u2019re capable of? We know the glory for a while and then fall back into\nseparateness, strife, division.\u201d<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Emersonian cadences of\nWitt\u2019s thoughts: --\u201cDarkness, light, strife, and love, are they the workings of\none mind? The features of the same face? Oh my soul, let me be in you now, look\nout through my eyes, look out at the things you made, all things shining.\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Private Witt, who,\nexamining the peaceful vistas provided by nature, wonders what propels men to\nwar. He is answered by Colonel Tall&nbsp; who\nsees instead that the vines wrap themselves around one another as though on a mission\nto choke the life out of the shrubbery.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Lt. Colonel Tall (Nick\nNolte), an aspiring Patton who's finally found his war. &nbsp;He hopes to get a promotion. It is his chance\nto prove his leadership abilities, and he will be ruthless in pursuit of glory.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nick Nolte does a&nbsp; high-powered turn as the always-hollering Lt.\nCol. Tall, and obviously put his heart and soul (as well as his voice box) into\nthe role.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Here the tension\nratchets up, as Tall must try and convince Captain Staros To lead his men up\nthe hill in a frontal assault against a Jap bunker with heavy guns in an\napparent &nbsp;suicide mission. . This tense\nmoment delineates the different kinds of courage which solders can exhibit\nunder pressure.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">At this VERY moment,\nThin Red Line metamorphoses into a great war film.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Captain Staros directly\nrefuses an order by Col. Tall to take a hill even ( with bullshit cries of &nbsp;&nbsp;<span style=\"background-color: white;\"><b>YEH DIL\nMAANGE MORE </b></span>) &nbsp;while Tall knows the\ncapture would involve the loss of many men.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Lt. Col. Gordon Tall,\nrose through the ranks in the U.S Army without ever going to war. Now that he\nhas his war, that he has his own battle</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Tall is like a fish in the water. &nbsp;&nbsp;Since he's not on the front lines, he doesn't\nquite grasp the extent of the carnage and pushes his men to their very limits.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nolte's performance is\na marvel of barely-controlled fury and a bridling need to prove his own\nfighting mettle; we know that Tall feels underestimated by his superiors and\nwishes to make Guadalcanal the arena in which he will earn the glory he\ndeserves and be born again.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Tall had been instructed\nby his commanding officer, General Quintard (played by John Travolta), to do so\n\u201cwithout mercy.\u201d &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The General reminds\nhim that the Admiral (played by nobody \u2013 a hopelessly high-up and hence utterly\noffscreen figure) will be watching the entire battle from afar, intimidating\nhim further with the political and perhaps moral truth \u201cThere\u2019s always someone\nwatching, like a hawk.\u201d <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">With this threat Tall\nvisibly loses his tree-like uprightness, wobbling into skeptical\nself-consciousness at the thought of being watched and evaluated every step of\nthe way by an authority eager to replace him if he fails to act in the interest\nof the war; a strategic and unhesitating sacrifice of the men who fight it is\ndeemed the only acceptable method<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Those with power\nexceeding their measure \u201cplay roles they never conceived\u201d (confessed by Tall\nvia interior monologue). <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Humans have power over\nnature and nature has power over humans \u2013 there is something almost symbiotic\nabout this back-and-forth tugging of power at this vast scale \u2013 but in\ndirecting the war rather than fighting it, upper rung figures like Tall and to\na lesser extent Staros are cut off from the real war, the war at the heart of\nnature, and suffer for it, paying the price of spiritual desolation (Tall) and\nspiritual desperation (Staros) <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Admiral is so\ncompletely removed from the film\u2019s sense of reality that he is not even\nrepresented as a human being at all, but rather as some sort of god-like\noverseer for the Americans who appear as tiny chess-size pieces that move\nwithin a finite range and according to plan. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The price for such a\nhigh degree of alienation is bound to be total, and the irony here is that his\npower in the war makes him extraneous to the real war and irrelevant to the\nmetaphysical stakes of The Thin Red Line, especially on the question whether\nsuch a person can harbor the \u201cone big soul that everyone is a part of.\u201d &nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-rI1w43w5m2Q/WYW9F9AEzbI/AAAAAAABVUk/f_W5I5D8JVg7dTHRCmdD2yVm_27mjTKQACLcBGAs/s1600/QuietinAg-Transcending-trrhe-Mind.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"345\" data-original-width=\"640\" height=\"344\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-rI1w43w5m2Q/WYW9F9AEzbI/AAAAAAABVUk/f_W5I5D8JVg7dTHRCmdD2yVm_27mjTKQACLcBGAs/s640/QuietinAg-Transcending-trrhe-Mind.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">After a maelstrom of\nconsternation and strenuous soul-searching over Colonel Tall\u2019s decision to\nlaunch a deadly frontal assault on the hill occupied by the Japanese, the\ncompany faces the long-awaited and spitefully dreaded moment of first blood\u2014the\nliving proof that the war, World War Two as it is written in the headlines and\nhistory books, is their war.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Colonel Tall's &nbsp;character can't be regarded as fully negative\nthough. His inner voice (the Colonel is heard off screen a few times too) shows\nthat he has a lots of complexes and they may be the main reason behind his\nbehavior.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/IPOYJ2jNDB0/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/IPOYJ2jNDB0?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Lieutenant Colonel Tall\norders the company commander, Captain James Staros, to take the bunker by\nfrontal assault, at whatever cost\u2014come what may. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Staros\nrefuses and Tall decides to join Staros on the front line to see the situation.\n&nbsp;The Japanese resistance seems to have\nlessened, and Tall's opinion of Staros seems to have been sealed. &nbsp;Insubordination in the thick of war , means\ncourt martial.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Captain Staros is\nrelieved of his command by Lieutenant Colonel Tall, who deems him too soft for\nthe pressures of combat and suggests that he apply for reassignment and become\na lawyer in the JAG in Washington. &nbsp;He\noffers to arrange a Purple Heart for Staros, to avoid the unit's name being\nstained by having an cowardly officer removed from command<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Right after Captain\nStaros has his big confrontation with Colonel Tall &nbsp;he hangs up the sound power and mutters in\nGreek. \"He's lost it. He doesn't know what he's saying.\" &nbsp;( Ta echi chasi aftos ).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This addition is to\nwhitewash the STEIN kosher thingy .&nbsp; In\nreality this muttering was to be in German</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Capt Staros has the\nhardest time coping, crumbling under the weight of lives lost for the greater\ngood of victory, so much so that he accepts his irrational dismissal from Tall\nas the only safe road back to civilized justice and sanity<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The chain of command\nbreaks when Capt Staros defies his superior officer Lt Col Tall. &nbsp;&nbsp;Tall delivers strict orders to Staros by\nphone once the fighting commences. &nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Admirals\nobserve the progress of colonels and colonels observe the progress of captains\nand captains observe the progress of privates with whom the chain of command\ncomes to an abrupt end, breaking off like a precipice and opening onto a front\nline where relations of power and perceptual logistics dissolve into a chaos of\nconfrontations beyond the reaches of military organization<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: purple; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; color: purple; font-size: large;\">Nick Nolte has the best\nlines in the film. &nbsp; &nbsp;He was perfectly cast as the hard ass Colonel who watches every\nmove of Captain Staros&nbsp; \"You don't\never have to say that I'm right Staros, we'll assume it\"</span><span style=\"font-size: 12pt;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/StO4BrFYq98/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/StO4BrFYq98?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Staros represents conscience,\nthe source of all guilt and sometimes strength.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Those \u201cin\u201d power,\nisolated and ensconced, can look on passively \u2013 and ironically quite\npowerlessly \u2013 through binoculars and communicate indirectly through telephone,\nbut in the process they distance themselves from the reality of death (the most\ndifficult yet elusive of all realities) and into a position we as viewers more\nor less find ourselves regarding everything we see and hear. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Staros, finds himself\nstationed behind the entire platoon directing the attack on behalf of Tall,\nobserves the suspenseful scene through binoculars<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is wrong to say that\nStaros is a coward and he is in a safe place \u2013only his men are in imminent harm\u2019s\nway<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Staros, represents an\ninteresting case in that he genuinely carries the burden of responsibility for\nthe welfare of his men, carries it deep within his soul, far away from the\ncodes of morality, rendering his position in the chain of command that much\nmore precarious, even torturous--</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">-- he must witness head-on the deaths he orders\nfrom just outside the reaches of death, just far enough back from the front\nline where he is protected from the brunt of enemy fire.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soldiers experience war\ndifferently than civilians, although either suffer in times of war, and women\nand children suffer unspeakable atrocities in particular. &nbsp;We know what happened in Libya, Iraq, Syria,\nYemen etc . <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The white Jew ( with\nthe help of Rothschild controlled UN )&nbsp;\nneeds to set man against man and milk the fruits.&nbsp; In the past decade, up to 2.45 million of\nthose killed in armed conflicts were innocent children. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The widespread trauma\ncaused by these atrocities and suffering of the civilian population is another\nlegacy of these conflicts, the following creates extensive emotional and\npsychological stress.&nbsp; The Thin Red Line\nopens our eyes\u2014it shows the agony of the Japanese soldier too.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Japanese throughout\nare totally depersonalized (in one crucial scene, their language is not even\ntranslated with subtitles); they aren't seen as enemies so much as necessary\nantagonists--an expression of nature's compulsion to \"contend with\nitself.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">One wonders what murky\nphilosophical voice-over questions were floating above the Japanese soldiers in\n\"The Thin Red Line.\" Were they also dreaming about nature, immortality,\nhumanity and death?<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The operation is a\nsuccess and C Company overruns one of the last Japanese strongholds on the\nisland. The Japanese they find are largely malnourished and dying of Malaria\ndysentery , and put up little resistance. The Japs were just happy to be done\nwith the war \u2013 eating a fellow Japanese for dinner does NOT boost the morale.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Each of these men the\nprotagonists of their own inner war, and yet nature lives and moves on without\nthem. And indeed, this indiscriminatory view of the world extends to the\nJapanese soldiers, who are feared&nbsp; in the\nfirst half when we never see them. Yet when their presence is finally known, we\nfind that they\u2019re just as frightened and lost as the Americans.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Malick also humanises\nthe enemy: he makes the Japanese both frightening and very human, when we see\nthem praying, or hopelessly surrendering to defeat<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the scene where the\nAmerican soldiers are sitting around among the Japanese prisoners after their\nbivouac ( Hill 210 ) is captured, you see an American soldier sitting next to\nand taunting a dying Japanese soldier. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Japanese soldier is\nretorting and what he is saying over and over to the American soldier is this:\nKisama mo itsuka shinun daiyo! Kisama is an unfriendly way to say you. Kind of\nlike saying \"you nasty person\" but the word is just \"you\".\nMo is \"too\". &nbsp;So he's basically saying \" you're gonna die one day\ntoo you\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Amid the bedlam, a\nburied face of a dead Japanese soldier speaks to Witt in voiceover, asking,\n\u201cAre you righteous? Loved by all? Know that I was, too.\u201d&nbsp;&nbsp; War brings death to both sides, and\nregardless of borders, it remains tragedy.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\">An American soldier goes round pulling out Japanese soldiers teeth and in one very touching scene he kneels down and says to the dying soldier \"Your gonna die now,... see those birds they;ll eat you alive\" ... -- the Japanese soldier responds \"What are you to me?...nothing\"--</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; line-height: 150%;\">- much later on the American soldier looks at the gold teeth and breaks down crying after hearing the dying words of the Japanese soldier, a very touching scene. This film gets you involved emotionally</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As the film approaches\nthe two-hour mark, for instance, a relatively minor character named Private\nDale (Arie Verveen) threatens a traumatized Japanese prisoner with brutal\ntreatment.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The captive, who doesn\u2019t understand a thing Dale is saying, speaks a\nfew soft phrases in Japanese, and in the background, Hans Zimmer\u2019s magisterial\nscore quotes the interrogative trumpet line of \u201cThe Unanswered Question,\u201d<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Below: The Unanswered Question\nis a musical work by American composer Charles Ives.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">Charles Edward Ives (\ndied 1954</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">was an American </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">composer. His great music was largely ignored\nduring his life, and many of his works went unperformed for many years.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">The music was used in\nThe Thin Red Line (1998), by Terrence Malik. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/WvP7JZWOZMw/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/WvP7JZWOZMw?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nothing very unusual\nhappens - soldiers get killed, go crazy with fear, fall out with superiors, and\ntry to find ways of surviving with body and mind intact.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">But while Malick is not overly preoccupied\nwith plot, the film's three hours are far from empty-- thematically,\nphilosophically and spiritually, no war movie has been so profoundly rich-\npantheist meditation on the role of conflict, violence and death<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A soldier rocking and\nsobbing in the rain for the horrors that he committed, stolen Jap teeth\ntumbling from his fingers.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Getting inside the\nheads of the Malick employs a novelistic technique used in his first two films\ntoo-- interior monologues.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;\"Property,\" Walsh says bitterly.\n\"It's all about property.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The film's centrepiece\nis the extended and savage campaign to destroy Japanese machine gun\nfortifications and take a crucial hill.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The fighting is almost\nan afterthought.. Placing scenes of deep introspection after scenes of carnage,\nMalick deliberately arranges his cinematic verse around anti-climax. After the\nJapanese bunker is captured, the commanding colonel (Nick Nolte), a despotic,\ncareer-driven alpha male, sits quietly, whittling, staring at something\nincomprehensible.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">We don't know what he's thinking, and we don't need to know.\nHe has achieved a military victory and has found that on the other side of\nglory lies a resounding silence.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">While the war may be\nnarrated from the point of view of the Americans, once the Japanese are\nrevealed behind their weapons and camouflage the film loses all sense of a\nvictor, as if each item in the rising death-toll bore a soul powerful enough to\ntip the scale of justice off its legs.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Japanese evacuated\nthe island in February of 1943.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In The Thin Red Line\nwhen Witt is killed by the Japanese soldiers, &nbsp;Malick cut later &nbsp;shots of him swimming with the Melanesians\nagain.&nbsp; &nbsp;The dimwit in the audience loses sense of linear\ntime and gets confused .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"avatar-image-container\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; float: left; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin: 0.2em 0px 0px; max-height: 36px; overflow: hidden; width: 36px;\">\n<img src=\"https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/zFdxGE77vvD2w5xHy6jkVuElKv-U9_9qLkRYK8OnbDeJPtjSZ82UPq5w6hJ-SA=s35\" style=\"border: 1px solid rgb(238, 238, 238); max-width: 36px;\" /></div>\n<div class=\"comment-block\" id=\"c1697369926406674377\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-left: 48px; position: relative;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_29M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/09873070011027410061\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">August 4, 2017 at 11:44 AM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_29MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nSuperb Captain simply superrrr,<br />\nKya movie kya director kya review<br />\nThis is a cinema heaven for me \ud83d\ude00<br />\nSince the movie was released in 1999 when I was in college, I have thought of this movie always. The only other person in my friend circle who liked it as much is Pulosto my close buddy.<br />\nI used to think we must be eccentric to like this movie so much. I have watched this movie sober, drunk and on weed.<br />\nIt brings out whole different layers and I catch different stuff. It is reality and that's why it's so hard. The reality of the tragic human condition and the reality of the severe harshness people are subjected to.<br />\nBen Chaplins character was so happy with the Melanesians. Amazing that you have actually been there \ud83d\ude00<br />\nAnd then he just goes to an inevitable death pushed by the military industrial complex.<br />\nDenied even a basic peaceful life. Every man is the same and that is the gut wrenching reality.<br />\nRegards</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" id=\"bc_0_29BR\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif;
