It\nalso holds 5,180 km of Indian territory in Pakistan occupied Kashmir under\nSino-Pak agreement of 1963. At the heart of Sino-Indian boundary dispute is the\nissue of Arunachal Pradesh (90,000 sq km), which China describes as\n\"Southern Tibet\". Beijing is demanding that at least the Tawang Tract\nof Arunachal Pradesh, if not the whole of the state, be transferred to China\u2026..&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Nepal :: China claims parts of Nepal dating back to the Sino-Nepalese War in\n1788-1792. China claims they are part of Tibet, therefore part of China. \u2026&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">North Korea :: Baekdu Mountain and Jiandao. China has also on occasion claimed\nall of North Korea on historical grounds (Yuan Dynasty, 1271-1368). \u2026&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The\nPhilippines :: Parts of the South China Sea, particularly Scarborough Shoal and\nthe Spratly Islands.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Russia :: 160,000 square kilometres still unilaterally\nclaimed by China, despite China signing several agreements.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Singapore :: Parts\nof the South China Sea. \u2026.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">South Korea :: Parts of the East China Sea. China\nhas also on occasion claimed all of South Korea on historical grounds (Yuan\nDynasty, 1271-1368)\u2026..&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Bhutan :: Bhutanese enclaves in Tibet, namely Cherkip\nGompa, Dho, Dungmar, Gesur, Gezon, Itse Gompa, Khochar, Nyanri, Ringung,\nSanmar, Tarchen and Zuthulphuk. Also Kula Kangri and mountainous areas to the\nwest of this peak, plus the western Haa District of Bhutan. \u2026&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Taiwan :: China\nclaims all of Taiwan, but particular disputes are: Macclesfi eld Bank, Paracel\nIslands, Scarborough Shoal, parts of the South China Sea and the Spratly\nIslands. The Paracel Islands, also called Xisha Islands in Vietnamese, is a\ngroup of islands in the South China Sea whose sovereignty is disputed among\nChina, Taiwan and Vietnam disputes with Burma. \u2026&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Kazakhstan :: There are continual\nunilateral claims by China on Kazakhstan territory, despite new agreements, in\nChina's favour signed every few years. \u2026&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Laos :: China claims large areas of\nLaos on historical precedent (China's Yuan Dynasty, 1271-1368)\u2026.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Brunei :: Over Spratly Islands. The Spratly\nIslands is a disputed group of more than 750 reefs, islets, atolls, cays, and\nislands in the South China Sea. About 45 islands are occupied by small numbers\nof military forces from the People's Republic of China, Taiwan, Vietnam, the Philippines,\nand Malaysia. Brunei has also claimed an exclusive economic zone in the\nsoutheastern part of the Spratlys encompassing just one area of small islands\non Louisa Reef. This has led to escalating tensions. \u2026&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Tajikistan :: Chinese\nclaims based on historical precedent (Qing Dynasty, 1644-1912). \u2026&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Cambodia ::\nChina has, on occasion, claimed parts of Cambodia on historical precedent\n(China's Ming Dynasty, 1368-1644). Indonesia :: Parts of the South China Sea. \u2026&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Kyrgyzstan :: China claims the majority of Kyrgyzstan on the grounds that it\nwas unfairly forced to cede the territory (which it had formerly conquered) to\nRussia in the 19th century. \u2026.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Malaysia :: Over Parts of the South China Sea,\nparticularly the Spratly Islands. \u2026&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Mongolia :: China claims all of Mongolia on\nhistorical precedent (Yuan Dynasty, 1271-1368). In fact, Mongolia, under\nGenghis Khan, occupied China. \u2026&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Afghanistan :: Afghan province of Bahdakhshan\n(despite a bilateral treaty of 1963, China still encroaches on Afghan\nterritory). \u2026 <o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-7TMkXFfi8_4/WXypA4OrlLI/AAAAAAABVIU/_qxQslHUNXkhlNA5h9I616DeR__WJP7lwCLcBGAs/s1600/170702064432321-south-china-sea-map-exlarge-169.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">If there is one thing at which China\u2019s\nleaders truly excel, it is the use of economic tools to advance their country\u2019s\ngeostrategic interests. \u2026Through its $1 trillion \u201cOne Belt, One Road\u201d\ninitiative, China is supporting infrastructure projects in strategically\nlocated developing countries, often by extending huge loans to their\ngovernments\u2026.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">As a result, countries are becoming ensnared in a debt trap that\nleaves them vulnerable to China\u2019s influence\u2026. The projects that China is\nsupporting are often intended not to support the local economy, but to\nfacilitate Chinese access to natural resources, or to open the market for\nlow-cost and shoddy SURPLUS Chinese goods\u2026&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">China is taking steps to ensure that\ncountries will not be able to escape their debts. In exchange for rescheduling\nrepayment, China is requiring countries to award it contracts for additional\nprojects, thereby making their debt crises interminable.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">China cancelled $90\nmillion of Cambodia\u2019s debt, only to secure major new contracts\u2026. New\ngovernments in several countries, from Nigeria to Sri Lanka, have ordered\ninvestigations into alleged Chinese bribery of the previous leadership. ..</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">China\nbegan investing heavily in Sri Lanka during the quasi-autocratic nine-year rule\nof President Mahinda Rajapaksa, and China shielded Rajapaksa at the UN from\nallegations of war crimes. China quickly became Sri Lanka\u2019s leading investor\nand lender, and its second-largest trading partner, giving it substantial\ndiplomatic leverage\u2026.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">It was smooth sailing for China, until Rajapaksa was\nunexpectedly defeated in the early 2015 election by Maithripala Sirisena, More\nthan 18 % of Chinese enterprises\u2019 \u2018interest coverage ratio\u2019 (ICR) is less than\n1, meaning those Chinese firms are still borrowing new loans to repay the old\nones..&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">China has fueled its explosive growth via a massive credit buildup..\nOBOR is a geopolitical architecture aimed at expanding Chinese influence in and\naround the region-- to lead much of the world into a debt trap..&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">OBOR\u2019s intent\nto create an infrastructure which would allow physical movement of goods, more\nspecifically EXCESS Chinese goods ( to keep Chinese employed and industries\nrunning ) , to large parts of Asia and Europe including Russia\u2026.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">China has\nperennial border disputes with almost all the countries it shares boundaries\nthrough land or sea. OBOR will be used to muscle Yuan as an alternate currency\nto the dollar--OBOR is a means towards economic colonisation by China\u2026.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">China suffers from too much capacity as well\nas too much domestic debt in their banking system. OBOR may provide a means for\nChina to deflate this debt while exporting overcapacity\u2026.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">What's more is that\nthey can do so while providing credit (at the state level) to countries who are\nin desperate need of it\u2026..Sri Lanka\u2019s Mattala Rajapaksa International Airport,\nwhich opened in 2013, is still largely idle and empty...&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">What does Sri Lanka\nnow get?.. An empty airport and a massive debt to China which they can't repay.\n\u2026</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Pakistan's multibillion dollar Gwadar port is another example\u2026..China controls\nall of this debt, and by controlling this debt they can, and will, begin using\nthis power for... ahem, \"concessions\"\u2026..</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The more China threatens\nIndia and the more it refuses to seek a compromise, the more it paints itself\nin a corner\u2026&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Gone are the days when India is afraid of China and banks on\nRussia to stop a Chinese attack\u2026.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">China has an almost $60 billion annual trade\nsurplus with India currently. India knows how to tighten the\nscrews\u2026..Sustainable growth is totally dependent when you consume what you produce.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">China CANNOT consume what it produces, even a significant percent of it\u2026..Mad\nmen ruling China has made 13.6 million flats ( homes ) unsold .. There are\nfully built cities that are having everything - but people..&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The construction\nis of such poor quality that the infrastructure is crumbling. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2018/05/comments-overflow-for-inoperative-load.html?showComment=1525771090590#c7174753694009767256\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">May 8, 2018 at 2:48 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_4MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\nCommunism collapsed 3 decades ago\u2014but our JNU commie and pathetic commie leaders keep the ideology alive..<br /><br />Jew Rothschild\u2019s cousin JEW Karl Marx did not invent communism. Radicals, including Pierre-Joseph Proudhon (1809-65) and the Chartist movement in England, had long used language that modern-day readers would identify as \u201cMarxist\u201d\u2014\u201cto enjoy political equality, abolish property\u201d; \u201creserve army of labour\u201d and so forth.<br /><br />What, then, was his contribution?<br /><br />Much of his time was spent disagreeing with other radicals, attacking Proudhon in particular, whom he likened to one of the \u201cbourgeois economists\u201d. Far more significantly, he attempted to provide an overall theoretical description of how capitalism worked, especially in Das Kapital, which was published in 1867.<br /><br />Marx's Das Kapital, fails to mention that money is printed out of thin air and keeps the name of his cousins, the Rothschilds, out of it, despite the fact that they were the richest and most powerful capitalist family in the whole world\u2026.<br /><br />Rothschild hired Marx to draft a social doctrine to invert moral order for centralizing their nation state\u2019s wealth Into Rothschild controlled coffers... Marx saw free trade as positive because it undermines established nations and cultures.<br /><br />Millions of people are still under the misapprehension that Marxism / Communism is against profiteering dishonest banks and multi national companies.. The Rothschild banking family - the richest and most powerful banksters, for the past 200 years - financed Karl Marx's pretense of an attack on the profiteering dishonest.banksters, in order to fool the masses, and it worked. ..<br /><br />Marx's hidden message was: \u201cForget your individual rights and privileges and trust in the State and the Trade Unions, and they'll do your thinking for you.\u201d ..Millions of people believed that nonsense, and subsequently allowed 'others' to do their thinking for them.<br /><br />The trade unions and the governments are ALL working for the Rothschild's - who own the banks, including Bank of England, US Federal Reserve,and all the big multi national companies, dangle politicians like rag dolls and hold all of the people as tax-debt slaves, through their corrupt central banks and their funny money.<br /><br />Marx's writing style was a calamity: full of sometimes puerile vehemence, Marx heaped scorn on his opponents, inaugurating the long Marxist tradition of mercilessly deriding anyone with incorrect opinions. In Marx\u2019s pamphlets, mudslinging abounds: Marx's heavy-handed insults tend to make us doubt Marx himself, since he relies so much on vituperation instead of reasoned argument.<br /><br />Marx's conclusion that aggregate price and profit are determined by\u2014and equal to\u2014aggregate value and surplus value is bullshit. There goes his his theory that the exploitation of workers is the sole source of profit.<br /><br />Marx's essential idea, was that capitalism would become less and less profitable and that its downward spiral toward the abyss of deflation\u2014lower prices, lower profits\u2014would be followed by worldwide revolution.<br /><br />The laws of dialectics at the very base of Marxism are fundamentally flawed-- some are \"truisms with no specific Marxist content\", others \"philosophical dogmas that cannot be proved by scientific means\", yet others just bullshit. Some Marxist \"laws\" are vague and can be interpreted differently, but these interpretations generally fall into one of the aforementioned categories of flaws as well.<br /><br />CONTINUED TO 2-</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"comment-replies\" id=\"bc_0_4BR\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2018/05/comments-overflow-for-inoperative-load.html?showComment=1525771153288#c6777305185001996910\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">May 8, 2018 at 2:49 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_1MC\" style=\"margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\nCONTINUED FROM 1-</div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\nGerman Jew Karl Marx had planned to write Das Kapital in multiple volumes. He finished the first. But when it came to writing the second, on realizing that he would face insurmountable intellectual hurdles ( including being charged of mindless plagiarism ) , he pleaded illness.. when in reality he was fit as a fiddle and going around doing everything else.</div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\nWhat Marx accomplished was to produce such a comprehensive, dramatic, and fascinating vision that it could withstand innumerable empirical contradictions, logical refutations, and moral revulsions at its effects.</div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\nThe Marxian vision took the overwhelming complexity of the real world and made the parts fall into place, in a way that was intellectually exhilarating and conferred such a sense of moral superiority that opponents could be simply labelled and dismissed as moral lepers or blind reactionaries.</div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\nMarxism was \u2013 and remains \u2013 a mighty instrument for the acquisition and maintenance of political power.</div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\nKarl Marx's value theory and law of the tendency of the rate of profit to fall are a crock of shit.</div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\nMarx does not even understand socialism. Socialism cannot be accomplished only through class conflict and a proletarian revolution.</div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\nCAPT AJIT VADAKAYIL DECLARES DAS KAPITAL IS THE BIGGEST TUB OF BULLSHIT.. EVER WRITTEN</div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\nIn the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations, Jew Rothschild\u2019s agent Adam Smith proposed that the free market, where producers are free to produce as much as they want and charge consumers the prices they want, would result in the most efficient and desirable economic outcome for consumers and producers alike due to the \u201cInvisible Hand.\u201d</div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\nThe rationale for his proposal was that each individual would try to maximize his own benefit. In doing so, consumers would only pay as much as or less than they would value the benefit derived from a good, and producers would only sell for as much as or higher than they would have spent on producing a good.</div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\nIn his idealistic economy, there would be no surplus or deficit supply or demand; markets would always be in equilibrium, and the benefits to consumers and producers alike would be maximized. There would be a limited role for the government in such an economic system.</div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\nIn contrast, Karl Marx in his Das Kapital reasoned that workers would be exploited by any capitalist, or factory owners, for the capitalist system provides an inherent advantage to the already rich and a disadvantage to the already poor segments of society. The rich would get richer and the poor would get poorer. Furthermore, the \u201ccapitalist\u201d is always in a better position to negotiate a low wage for his workers, he argued.</div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\nOne of his notable and more contentious theories \u2013 the labor theory of value \u2013 claims that the value of a good or service is directly connected to the amount of labor required for its production. Interestingly, Karl Marx also had his own drastic, political ideas that were far away from those of Adam Smith\u2019s.</div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"color: red; font-size: small;\">Adam Smith?
